title: Familial cases and male cases with MECP2 mutations
author: Zhang Q, et al.

cases.description: In family A, the mother (family A, I:1), her daughter (family A, II:1), and her son (family A, II:2) had identical MECP2 mutation c.397C > T (p.R133C). II:1, the proband, an 8 years 8 months old girl... Her clinical manifestations met the diagnostic criteria for PSV.
cases.family_history: Non-consanguineous Chinese parents; mother carries same MECP2 mutation.
cases.notes: XCI of daughter 59:41 (random). EEG showed focal spike and slow waves in left temporal regions.
quotes: In family A (Figure 1A), the mother (family A, I:1), her daughter (family A, II:1), and her son (family A, II:2) had identical MECP2 mutation c.397C > T (p.R133C).
II:1, the proband, an 8 years 8 months old girl...
She developed stereotypic hand movements and marked teeth grinding and lost her ability to use her fingers...
Poor eye-contact and no-interest in holding things were noticed before age of 6 months.
Her clinical manifestations met the diagnostic criteria for PSV.
XCI of daughters | Family A | 59:41 (Table 1).

phenotypic_evidence.core_asd_symptoms: Poor eye contact; stereotypic hand movements; loss of hand skills; language regression/impairment.
phenotypic_evidence.developmental_milestones: Sat 8 months; spoke simple words at 12 months; walked at 18 months; later regression of hand use and language.
phenotypic_evidence.comorbidities: Teeth grinding; EEG focal spike and slow waves; no seizures reported.

variant.variant_description: Hotspot MECP2 missense variant associated with PSV/atypical RTT.
variant.segregation_data: Mother I:1 and brother II:2 share identical MECP2 mutation; fathers tested negative per cohort summary.

quotes: Patient 1 (missense mutation: R133C) current age: 9 years (Results, 3.1 Patient 1)
She could communicate with short sentences but echolalia was noted. (Results, 3.1 Patient 1)
Her intelligence quotient (IQ) was 23 (TanakaBinet) at 7 years of age, which might be underestimated because of her poor performance skills and social interaction. (Results, 3.1 Patient 1)
Genomic DNAs from 35 Japanese sporadic patients with Rett syndrome (RTT) were screened… (Abstract)
All the RTT patients screened in this study were sporadic and typical except for five patients with preserved speech variants. (Results, Section 3)
C472T -> R133C (Table 1, Missense C472T R133C; PSV column indicates preserved speech variant)

phenotypic_evidence.comorbidities: Afebrile seizures (twice); abnormal breathing behavior (breath-holding); stereotyped hand movements.

cases.description: Patient 5 (two nucleotide mutation at 543, 544 TC of MECP2) current age: 21 years. At the age of 40 months, she was diagnosed as having autistic disorder.
cases.cohort_name: Rett syndrome preserved speech variant patients followed at Kurume University Hospital (Japanese cohort)
cases.family_history: All the RTT patients screened in this study were sporadic.
cases.notes: Preserved speech variant of Rett syndrome; novel two-nucleotide deletion; milder speech and motor function reported.
quotes: 3.5. Patient 5 (two nucleotide mutation at 543, 544 TC of MECP2) current age: 21 years (Results, 3.5 Patient 5)
At the age of 40 months, she was diagnosed as having autistic disorder. (Results, 3.5 Patient 5)
She showed mild breathing abnormalities and scoliosis but had no microcephaly. (Results, 3.5 Patient 5)
EEG was abnormal with right centrotemporal spikes at 60 months of age. She developed epilepsy at 17 years of age. (Results, 3.5 Patient 5)
543,544(TC) 2 bp del (Table 1, Frameshift and stop 543,544(TC) 2 bp del; PSV column indicates preserved speech variant)

One patient with preserved speech had a novel two-nucleotide deletion mutation at 543, 544 TC of MECP2, leading to the replacement of amino acids at 183-233 codons and causing a premature termination at 233 codon in 486 amino acids of the normal MECP2 product. The putative protein has a normal methyl-binding domain (MBD), but is missing a transcriptional repression domain (TRD). (Discussion)

phenotypic_evidence.core_asd_symptoms: Autistic disorder (diagnosed at 40 months).
phenotypic_evidence.developmental_milestones: Head control 3 months; rolling over 5 months; sitting 7–8 months; walking alone 13 months; spoke three words at 18 months; two-word sentences at 24 months; eye contact became poor at 24 months.
phenotypic_evidence.comorbidities: Mild breathing abnormalities; scoliosis; abnormal EEG with right centrotemporal spikes at 60 months; epilepsy at 17 years; no microcephaly.

variant.variant_description: Novel two-nucleotide deletion in MECP2 (positions 543–544) causing frameshift; predicted to truncate the protein at codon 233.
variant.impact: frameshift resulting in premature termination; loss of TRD with intact MBD

title: Clinical profiles of four patients with Rett syndrome carrying a novel exon 1 mutation or genomic rearrangement in the MECP2 gene
author: Bartholdi D, et al.

cases.description: Sequencing showed c.30delCinsGA, a combination of deletion and insertion in exon 1, which is predicted to lead to a frameshift and a premature stop codon (p.Ser10ArgfsX32). She developed stereotypic hand movements with loss of purposeful hand use between the second and third year of age.
cases.family_history: Unaffected parents; mutation not detected in either parent
cases.notes: X-inactivation: borderline skewing (70%:30%) with preferential activation of the paternal allele; died at 19 years from pneumonia.
quotes: Sequencing showed c.30delCinsGA, a combination of deletion and insertion in exon 1 (Fig. 1), which is predicted to lead to a frameshift and a premature stop codon (p.Ser10ArgfsX32).
Neither of the unaffected parents harbored this mutation.
Twenty girls with a clinical diagnosis of RTT were selected for this study.
For all four patients in whom we identified a mutation, severity was scored using the guidelines for reporting clinical features in cases with MECP2 mutations (17) (Table 2).
Completion of scoring revealed 37 out of 40 points, indicating severe abnormality in 17 out of 20 features (Table 2).
She developed stereotypic hand movements with loss of purposeful hand use between the second and third year of age.

phenotypic_evidence.core_asd_symptoms: stereotypic hand movements; loss of purposeful hand use; regression of motor ability; no speech
phenotypic_evidence.diagnostic_criteria_used: Revised clinical criteria for RTT (Hagberg et al., 2002)
phenotypic_evidence.assessment_tools_used: Kerr et al. 2001 clinical severity scoring for MECP2 cases
phenotypic_evidence.cognitive_assessment_results: Kerr severity score 37/40 (Table 2); Intellectual disability: score 2 (Table 2).
phenotypic_evidence.cognitive_ability_cautionary_comment: No standardized IQ provided; ID severity not clearly classified.
phenotypic_evidence.developmental_milestones: Mild developmental delay in first year; sat unaided and used two words at 12 months; did not learn to walk; regression of motor ability between 2–3 years.
phenotypic_evidence.comorbidities: severe feeding difficulties; scoliosis; sleep disturbances; epileptic seizures (poorly controlled); microcephaly (head circumference <3rd centile by 2.5 years); joint contractures; muscular wasting
phenotypic_evidence.phenotypes: Rett syndrome phenotype with regression and stereotypies

variant.variant_description: Combination of deletion and insertion in exon 1 detected by sequencing; predicted to truncate the protein.
variant.segregation_data: Neither of the unaffected parents harbored this mutation.

cases.description: Multiplex ligation-dependent probe amplification resulted in decreased relative peak heights of fragments corresponding to exons 1 and 2, suggesting the deletion of these exons. She did not learn to sit unaided ... She achieved only borderline hand use ... and did not produce any words.
cases.family_history: Unaffected parents; alteration not detected in either parent
cases.notes: X-inactivation: clear skewing (93%:7%) with preferential activation of the maternal allele.
quotes: Multiplex ligation-dependent probe amplification resulted in decreased relative peak heights of fragments corresponding to exons 1 and 2, suggesting the deletion of these exons (Fig. 1).
The alteration was not detected in the DNAs of the unaffected parents.
Twenty girls with a clinical diagnosis of RTT were selected for this study.
For all four patients in whom we identified a mutation, severity was scored using the guidelines for reporting clinical features in cases with MECP2 mutations (17) (Table 2).
Scoring revealed 33 out of 40 points (Table 2), reflecting the severe phenotype of this girl.
She did not learn to sit unaided and started to shuffle with 12 months. She achieved only borderline hand use (incomplete palmar grasp, no pincer grasp) and did not produce any words.
The first generalized epileptic seizures occurred at the age of 4 years.

cases.description: MLPA showed decreased relative peak heights of fragments corresponding to exon 3 and the coding region of exon 4, suggesting at least partial deletion of these exons. cases.family_history: Only mother tested (normal MLPA profile); paternal sample not available
cases.notes: X-inactivation: skewed (83%:17%) with preferential activation of the maternal allele; follow-up not available after age 14.
quotes: Multiplex ligation-dependent probe amplification showed decreased relative peak heights of fragments corresponding to exon 3 and the coding region of exon 4, suggesting at least partial deletion of these exons (Fig. 1).
Only the mother's DNA was available for MLPA analysis and revealed a normal profile.
During the second year of life marked autistic behavior with lack of eye contact became apparent; she did not speak and developed stereotypic hand movements.
Twenty girls with a clinical diagnosis of RTT were selected for this study.
For all four patients in whom we identified a mutation, severity was scored using the guidelines for reporting clinical features in cases with MECP2 mutations (17) (Table 2).
This girl obtained 19 out of 40 points, reflecting a mild phenotype with near-normal hand use, locomotion and lack of microcephaly (Table 2).

title: MECP2 Mutation in a Boy with Severe Neonatal Encephalopathy: Clinical, Neuropathological and Molecular Findings
author: Geerdink N, et al.

cases.description: The family history included a sister who was mentally retarded with autistic features. She was diagnosed as having RS when her brother was 8 months old. MECP2 mutation analysis with direct sequencing revealed a 488-489del in the patient's sister with RS (Fig. 3c). This mutation induced a frameshift and led to a truncated protein after ten amino acids.
cases.family_history: Brother (index case) had severe neonatal encephalopathy and carried the same MECP2 mutation hemizygously; mother negative in blood and likely germline mosaic; another sister healthy.
cases.notes: Sister is heterozygous carrier of the MECP2 488-489del; diagnosed with Rett syndrome with autistic features. Exact age and assessments not provided. File reference: Main text: Clinical findings; Molecular analysis; Fig. 3 caption.
quotes: The family history included a sister who was mentally retarded with autistic features.
She was diagnosed as having RS when her brother was 8 months old.
MECP2 mutation analysis with direct sequencing revealed a 488-489del in the patient’s sister with RS (Fig. 3c).
This mutation induced a frameshift and led to a truncated protein after ten amino acids, and was therefore almost certainly pathologic.
The same mutation was found heterozygously in the affected sister (panel c).
The mutation could not be identified in DNA isolated from blood of the mother, who is likely to carry the mutation in her germ-line.

phenotypic_evidence.core_asd_symptoms: Autistic features noted in clinical history.
phenotypic_evidence.cognitive_ability_cautionary_comment: Severity of intellectual disability not quantified; inability to speak or walk suggests severe to profound impairment, but not explicitly stated.
phenotypic_evidence.developmental_milestones: Not able to speak or to walk.
phenotypic_evidence.comorbidities: Intellectual disability; speech impairment; gait impairment.
phenotypic_evidence.phenotypes: Rett syndrome; autistic features.

variant.sequencing_method_details: MECP2 mutation analysis with direct sequencing; family testing as shown in Fig. 3c.
variant.variant_description: Two-base deletion (488-489del) in MECP2 exon 3 (deletion of two G residues); heterozygous in sister with Rett syndrome; frameshift leading to truncated protein after ten amino acids.
variant.segregation_data: Mother tested negative in blood and is likely germ-line mosaic. Brother was hemizygous for the same mutation.

title: Case Report: De novo DDX3X mutation caused intellectual disability in a female with skewed X-chromosome inactivation on the mutant allele
author: Sun Y, et al.

cases.description: The proband was a 10-year-old girl without family history. The symptoms of the proband included mild to moderate intellectual disability, delayed psychomotor development, poor speech development, infantile hypotonia, autism, and behavior problems. At the age of 7 years, she was diagnosed as autism spectrum disorder, the scores of childhood autism rating scale and autistic behavior checklist were 32 and 75.
cases.family_history: without family history
cases.notes: Extreme skewed X-chromosome inactivation with mutant allele on maternal X predominantly inactive; RNA allelic expression in PBMCs wild:mut ~71:29. ASD assessment scores: CARS=32; ABC=75.
quotes: “The proband was a 10-year-old girl without family history.” (Patient)

“The symptoms of the proband included mild to moderate intellectual disability, delayed psychomotor development, poor speech development, infantile hypotonia, autism, and behavior problems.” (Patient)
“At the age of 7 years, she was diagnosed as autism spectrum disorder, the scores of childhood autism rating scale and autistic behavior checklist were 32 and 75.” (Patient)
“Trio-based exome sequencing revealed a de novo heterozygous variant of NM_001193416.3: c.694_711dup18 (NC_000023.10: g.41203004_41203021dup18) in DDX3X gene of the female proband.” (Result)
“It indicated that the variant of NM_001193416.3: c.694_711dup18 occurred on the maternal X chromosome.” (Result)
“II.1 exhibited extreme skewing of XCI. The inactivated X-chromosome was linked with the 289 bp peak of AR, which inherited from the mother I.2.” (Figure 1C legend)
“The read counts for the DDX3X wild and mutant alleles were 586 and 244 (71:29), respectively, indicating that the mutant allele had lower expression (Figure 1D).” (Lower expression section)

phenotypic_evidence.core_asd_symptoms: Autism spectrum disorder diagnosis with behavior problems and poor speech development; standardized assessments administered (CARS, ABC).
phenotypic_evidence.assessment_tools_used: Childhood Autism Rating Scale (CARS); Autistic Behavior Checklist (ABC)
phenotypic_evidence.cognitive_assessment_results: Mild to moderate intellectual disability reported; language level at 26 months equivalent to 12.7 months (Sym score: 5).
phenotypic_evidence.developmental_milestones: Could not sit without support at 18 months; began to walk at 2 years; language level at 26 months equivalent to 12.7 months (Sym score: 5).
phenotypic_evidence.comorbidities: Infantile hypotonia; mild to moderate intellectual disability.
phenotypic_evidence.phenotypes: Delayed psychomotor development; poor speech development; behavior problems; sporadic spike-and-slow wave complexes on VEEG; brain MRI normal; abnormal cerebral blood flows in middle and anterior cerebral arteries on Doppler ultrasound.

variant.sequencing_method: Trio-based whole-exome sequencing with Sanger validation
variant.sequencing_method_details: Parental phasing by SNP haplotypes indicating maternal X; AR assay showed maternal X predominantly inactive; RNA-seq in PBMCs showed allelic imbalance (wild:mut ~71:29).
variant.region: Exon 8; D1 domain region (between RNA and ATP binding sites)
variant.variant_description: De novo heterozygous 18-bp in-frame duplication in DDX3X exon 8 on the maternal X chromosome; extreme skewed X-inactivation inactivating the maternal mutant X; mutant allele shows reduced expression (~29%) in PBMCs.
variant.impact: In-frame duplication of six amino acids in a conserved region; classified as likely pathogenic (ACMG 1PS + 2PM).
variant.segregation_data: Parents wild-type by Sanger. SNP-based phasing showed duplication on maternal X; AR assay indicated maternal X predominantly inactive; RNA-seq allele counts wild:mut ≈ 586:244.

cases.score_rationale: Variant: in_frame (de_novo) | Initial score: 0.5 (range: 0-1.0) | Final quantized score: 0.5

title: A novel hypomorphic MECP2 point mutation is associated with a neuropsychiatric phenotype
author: Adegbola AA, et al.

cases.description: The proband, a 10-year old nondysmorphic female, presented with primarily neuropsychiatric manifestations and obesity with relative sparing of intelligence, language, growth, and gross motor skills. She was diagnosed with pervasive developmental disorder-not otherwise specified (PDD-NOS) at age 7 because of her insistence on sameness, preference for rituals, chronic inflexibility, inability to sustain conversations, and poor recognition of verbal and nonverbal cues. MECP2 sequencing identified a heterozygous c.454C>G (p.P152A) variant in exon 4, located in the methyl-binding domain; the same variant was present in her father.
cases.family_history: Father (46,XY) carries the same MECP2 c.454C>G (p.P152A) variant and has a history of behavioral dyscontrol, hyperactivity, anxiety, socialization and cognitive difficulties, and a learning disability; paternal grandmother reportedly has short stature, obesity, and cognitive problems (not genetically tested).
cases.notes: X-inactivation in proband was random (57:43). EEG abnormal with multifocal sharp and spike wave discharges but no seizures. BMI 35.7. Head circumference tracked at ~98th percentile; described as macrocephalic with mild kyphosis in discussion.
quotes: The proband, a 10-year old nondysmorphic female, is the only child of her parents.

She was diagnosed with pervasive developmental disorder-not otherwise specified (PDD-NOS) at age 7 because of her insistence on sameness, preference for rituals, chronic inflexibility, inability to sustain conversations, and poor recognition of verbal and nonverbal cues.
Her electroencephalogram (EEG) is abnormal with multifocal sharp and spike wave discharges, but no visualized seizure activity.

MECP2 gene sequencing (coding regions and flanking splice sites) revealed a single heterozygous nucleotide variant, c.454C>G in exon 4 (Genbank Accession Number NM_004992.2), resulting in the change of a proline to an alanine residue, p.P152A.
The same sequence variant was present in the father, who had a 46,XY karyotype in peripheral blood.
We identified and characterized a novel missense mutation (c.454C>G; p.P152A) in the critical methyl-binding domain of MeCP2 that disrupts MeCP2 functional activity.
The p.P152A mutation showed an approximate 40% decrease in its association with insoluble heterochromatin compared to wild-type.
WISC-IV revealed a full-scale intelligence quotient (FSIQ) in the mild ID range (Table 1).
The proband was administered the Bruininks-Oseretsky test of motor proficiency (BOT-2) ... which revealed a fine motor composite score of 20 (less than the first percentile).
8 years and 7 months revealed a Koppitz developmental score of 10 (fifth percentile), consistent with perceptual-motor difficulties.
Presence of autistic behavior: Mild; diagnosis of PDD-NOS.

phenotypic_evidence.core_asd_symptoms: Insistence on sameness; preference for rituals; chronic inflexibility; inability to sustain conversations; poor recognition of verbal and nonverbal cues; occasional hand-wringing stereotypies.
phenotypic_evidence.cognitive_assessment_results: WISC-IV at 6y11m: FSIQ 70 (2nd %ile), Verbal 83 (13th), Perceptual Reasoning 69 (2nd), Working Memory 91 (27th), Processing Speed 56 (0.2nd). WISC-IV at 8y: FSIQ 58 (0.3rd), Verbal 81 (10th), Perceptual Reasoning 57 (0.2nd), Working Memory 65 (1st), Processing Speed 59 (0.3rd). BOT-2 fine motor composite 20 (<1st %ile). Koppitz developmental score at 8y7m: 10 (5th %ile).
phenotypic_evidence.cognitive_ability_cautionary_comment: It is possible that behavioral problems associated with the proband's diagnosis of PDD-NOS prevented valid IQ testing, though adaptive behaviors as reported by teachers and parents are consistent with mild ID.
phenotypic_evidence.developmental_milestones: Normal early development; slowing of motor skills and hypotonia began at 12 months without documented regression; purposeful hand movements with occasional hand-wringing stereotypies.
phenotypic_evidence.comorbidities: Mild intellectual disability; morbid obesity (BMI 35.7); abnormal EEG with multifocal sharp and spike wave discharges (no seizures observed); genu valgum (knock-knees); pes planus (flat feet); macrocephaly (~98th percentile head circumference); mild kyphosis; frequent episodic aggressive outbursts; hypotonia; fine motor dysfunction; perceptual-motor difficulties.
phenotypic_evidence.phenotypes: Nondysmorphic; macrocephaly; mild kyphosis; genu valgum; pes planus; hypotonia; fine motor impairment; abnormal EEG without seizures; obesity; behavioral dyscontrol and aggressive outbursts.

variant.sequencing_method: Single-gene sequencing of MECP2 (coding regions and flanking splice sites)
variant.sequencing_method_details: Sanger sequencing of MECP2 coding regions and flanking splice sites; variant not observed in 100 control individuals; not reported in RettBASE at time of study.
variant.variant_description: Novel missense mutation not reported in RettBASE; absent in 100 control individuals tested.
variant.impact: Predicted probably damaging by PolyPhen; not tolerated by SIFT; approximately 40% reduction in heterochromatin binding compared to wild-type; disrupts MeCP2 functional activity.
variant.segregation_data: Variant also present in father (46,XY) with neuropsychiatric/learning disability phenotype; no evidence of mosaicism or 47,XXY in blood.

functional_data.result_summary: ~40% decrease in association with insoluble heterochromatin vs wild-type
functional_data.interpretation: Functional impairment consistent with disrupted MeCP2 activity

cases.score_rationale: Variant: missense (paternal) | Initial score: 0.1 (range: 0-0.1) | Final quantized score: 0.1

title: First report of an unusual novel double mutation affecting the transcription repression domain of MeCP2 and causing a severe phenotype of Rett syndrome: Molecular analyses and computational investigation
author: Ghorbel R, et al.

cases.description: "The proband was native of northern Tunisia and was 4 years old girl, born from a non consanguineous marriage." "The patient showed clinical features fulfilling the main revised diagnostic criteria for typical Rett syndrome. Indeed, she showed a severe intellectual disability, an infantile encephalopathy with an autistic behavior." "The results revealed the presence of a novel de novo double-mutation in the exon 4 of the MECP2 gene: a new mutation c.695G > T (p.G232V) and the common c.880 C > T transition (p.R294X) (Fig. 1A)."
cases.cohort_name: Department of Child and Adolescent Neurology, National Institute Mongi Ben Hmida of Neurology, Tunis, Tunisia
cases.family_history: Non-consanguineous parents; one healthy sister; parents unaffected.
cases.notes: Two heterozygous de novo variants reported in exon 4 affecting the TRD domain; phase (cis/trans) not stated. Sources: Section 2.1 Patient; Section 3.1 Mutational analyses.
quotes: The proband was native of northern Tunisia and was 4 years old girl, born from a non consanguineous marriage.
The patient showed clinical features fulfilling the main revised diagnostic criteria for typical Rett syndrome.
Indeed, she showed a severe intellectual disability, an infantile encephalopathy with an autistic behavior.
In addition, this patient developed epilepsy in the age of 12 months. Besides, motor development delay and sleep disorder were detected in the studied patient.
Onset of stereotypic hand movements, severe cognitive impairment with absence of language, progressive scoliosis and autistic features were revealed.
The extensive sequencing of the four exons of the MECP2 gene and their flanking exon-intron boundaries was performed in the Tunisian patient with Rett syndrome and her family members.
The results revealed the presence of a novel de novo double-mutation in the exon 4 of the MECP2 gene: a new mutation c.695G > T (p.G232V) and the common c.880 C > T transition (p.R294X) (Fig. 1A).
In fact, the novel transition c.695G > T was present in the studied patient at heterozygous state... Besides it is a de novo mutation since it was absent in the patient's parents.
In addition, the common c.880 C > T transition was present at heterozygous state in the studied patient and was absent in her unaffected parents and sister.

phenotypic_evidence.phenotypes: Typical Rett syndrome with stereotypic hand movements; progressive scoliosis.

variant.sequencing_method_details: Sequencing of all four MECP2 exons and flanking exon-intron boundaries in proband and family members (Sanger); parental and sibling testing performed.
variant.variant_description: Novel de novo double-mutation in MECP2 exon 4: missense c.695G>T (p.G232V) and nonsense c.880C>T (p.R294X), both heterozygous and absent in parents and sister.
variant.impact: p.R294X predicts truncation (loss-of-function); p.G232V predicted deleterious; both in TRD domain.
variant.segregation_data: Both variants heterozygous in proband; absent in parents and sister (de novo).

title: Novel de novo Nonsense Mutation of MECP2 in a Patient with Rett Syndrome
author: Kim S, et al.

cases.description: "She was found to have a novel heterozygous nonsense mutation, 129C>T (Q19X), which leads to the most severely truncated MECP2 protein reported to date. Sequencing of parental DNA revealed the mutation was de novo. The patient was not affected with microcephaly or hyperventilation, but had other features of Rett syndrome including severe mental retardation and symptoms of autistic disorder."
cases.notes: Moderately skewed X-chromosome inactivation (1.74:1) reported. No microcephaly; normal respiratory pattern. Fragile X ruled out; Angelman syndrome suspected but 15q11-q13 deletion not found and UPD not assessed.
quotes: [Abstract] "She was found to have a novel heterozygous nonsense mutation, 129C>T (Q19X), which leads to the most severely truncated MECP2 protein reported to date. Sequencing of parental DNA revealed the mutation was de novo. The patient was not affected with microcephaly or hyperventilation, but had other features of Rett syndrome including severe mental retardation and symptoms of autistic disorder."
[Patient] "The patient was a five-year-old girl at the time of evaluation."
[Patient] "She had had a regression in purposeful hand movements, lost speech consisting of a few single words, lost eye gaze and lost social smiling in the latter her second year."
[Patient] "Complex partial seizures were identified at 22 months and treated with carbamazepine."
[Patient] "She had continuous patting and clasping movements of her hands."
[Patient] "She did not have microcephaly (head circumference 47.25 cm at 24 months and 51 cm at 59 months). She had a normal respiratory pattern."
[Patient] "a consulting pediatric neurologist diagnosed RTT one month before our evaluation"
[Results and Discussion] "The patient was found to have a heterozygous nonsense mutation of MECP2 : 129C>T leading to Q19X (Fig. 1)."
[Results and Discussion] "Neither of the parents' DNA showed a mutation, demonstrating this is a de novo mutation."
[Results and Discussion] "A moderately skewed XCI pattern (1.74:1) may have contributed to the absence of microcephaly and hyperventilation."
[Figure 1 legend] "Y indicates C/T transition at nucleotide position 129 in X99686."

phenotypic_evidence.core_asd_symptoms: Regression of language (loss of single words), loss of social smiling and eye gaze, stereotyped hand movements; symptoms of autistic disorder reported.
phenotypic_evidence.cognitive_assessment_results: Severe mental retardation; cognitive and language function less than one year in all areas.
phenotypic_evidence.cognitive_ability_cautionary_comment: Severe ID present; no formal ASD diagnosis or gold-standard tools reported (A/B/C not met), so ASD association confidence is reduced.
phenotypic_evidence.developmental_milestones: Regression in late second year; loss of purposeful hand movements; loss of speech; cognitive and language function less than one year in all areas.
phenotypic_evidence.comorbidities: Rett syndrome; complex partial seizures (onset 22 months) treated with carbamazepine; mild ataxia; slightly spastic gait; no microcephaly; normal respiratory pattern.
phenotypic_evidence.phenotypes: Rett syndrome features with regression, stereotyped hand movements, severe ID; seizures; ataxia; spastic gait; absent microcephaly; normal respiration.

variant.variant_description: Novel de novo nonsense mutation at nucleotide 129 (referenced to X99686), p.Q19X/p.Gln19Ter; the most severely truncated MECP2 reported at the time.
variant.segregation_data: Neither parent carried the mutation; confirmed de novo by sequencing of parental DNA.

title: Three intellectual disability-associated de novo mutations in MECP2 identified by trioWES analysis
author: Gu Y, et al.

cases.description: The 8-year-old girl (case 2) carries the p.(Arg306Cys) mutation. At 3 years and 1 month, she was found to avoid eye-contact and interaction with others. Clancy Behavior Scale measurement suggested possible autism. Although this patient had hand stereotypy, her normal head growth did not support the diagnosis of RTT. Considering her overall developmental delay and autistic-like features after 6 months, the diagnosis of Xlinked ID, psychomotor retardation and possible Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) was made.
cases.notes: Sanger sequencing confirmed de novo status; EEG showed multifocal epileptic-like discharges without clinical seizures; brain MRI and AEP were normal.
quotes: The 8-year-old girl (case 2, Fig. 2b), who carries the p.(Arg306Cys) mutation, was healthy at birth.
At 3 years and 1 month, she was found to avoid eye-contact and interaction with others.
Clancy Behavior Scale measurement suggested possible autism.
At 7 years and 4 months, she showed stereotypic hand movements; her height was 117 cm (15-50th), body weight was 24 kg (50th). Brain MRI and AEP were normal.

Although this patient had hand stereotypy, her normal head growth did not support the diagnosis of RTT [10]. Considering her overall developmental delay and autistic-like features after 6 months, the diagnosis of Xlinked ID, psychomotor retardation and possible Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) was made [18].

A nonsense [NC_000023.10: g.153296777G > A, NM_ 004992.3: c.502C > T, p.(Arg168*)] and two missense mutations [NC_000023.10: g.153296363G > A, NM_ 004992.3: c.916C > T, p.(Arg306Cys); NC_000023.10: g.153296400G > C, NM_004992.3: c.879C > G, p.(Ile293Met)] in exon 4 of MECP2 were identified in case 1, case 2 and case 3 respectively.
All of the mutations were de novo heterozygous in the affected individuals.
Fig. 2 Sanger sequencing of the mutation c.916C > T, p.(Arg360Cys) of MECP2 in case 2. a The mutation is present in the proband, but not in the parents, is confirmed by Sanger sequencing.
Although she did not have a seizure history, EEG detected multifocal epileptic-like discharges during her sleep.

phenotypic_evidence.core_asd_symptoms: Avoids eye contact; avoids interaction with others; stereotypic hand movements
phenotypic_evidence.cognitive_ability_cautionary_comment: Intellectual disability reported without severity or standardized cognitive testing; ASD characterization noted as 'possible'.
phenotypic_evidence.developmental_milestones: Smiled at 3 months; sat steadily at 6 months; crawled and grasped at 12 months. At 24 months developed pincer grasp, independent stand, and responded to name; at 30 months began to babble and walked with abnormal gait.
phenotypic_evidence.comorbidities: X-linked intellectual disability; psychomotor retardation; EEG with multifocal epileptic-like discharges (no clinical seizures).
phenotypic_evidence.phenotypes: Abnormal gait; normal brain MRI and AEP.

variant.sequencing_method_details: De novo status confirmed by Sanger sequencing; variant absent in parents.
variant.variant_description: Missense substitution p.Arg306Cys in MECP2 exon 4; de novo, heterozygous; previously reported allele located in transcriptional repression domain (TRD).
variant.impact: Located within the transcriptional repression domain; recurrent allele in MECP2.
variant.segregation_data: Variant present in proband and absent in both parents by Sanger sequencing (de novo).

title: Identification of autism-related MECP2 mutations by whole-exome sequencing and functional validation
author: Zhu W, et al.

cases.description: We identified three missense mutations of MECP2 from three autism patients by whole-exome sequencing: p.P152L (c.455C>T) ... Among these mutations, p.P152L ... [was] de novo. In CRF, P.138 matched all items of social and language ... The score of child autism rating scale (CARS) of P.138 ... was 30 ... ABC ... 158 ... all of them achieved standard of diagnosing autism.
cases.cohort_name: Shanghai Mental Health Center ASD cohort (120 core families; 2013–2015)
cases.family_history: None of the three patients have familial history of psychiatric disorders or neuropathy.
cases.notes: RTT excluded. Additional variants reported in NRXN1 (c.4180A>T; p.T1394S) and CACNA1C (c.5564G>A; p.C1855Y), both inherited from unaffected father. Onset at age 3, diagnosed at age 5.
quotes: We identified three missense mutations of MECP2 from three autism patients by whole-exome sequencing: p.P152L (c.455C>T), p.P376S (c.1162C>T), and p.R294X (c.880C>T). Among these mutations, p.P152L and p.R294X were de novo mutations, whereas p.P376S was inherited maternally. (Results)
Table 1 Summary of variations in ASD patients carrying MECP2 mutations: 138 F MECP2 ChrX Position (Hg19) 153,296,824 Nucleotide c.455C>T Amino acid p.P152L Transmission De novo
All patients were diagnosed on the basis of the fourth edition of the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-IV). (Subjects)

The score of child autism rating scale (CARS) of P.138, P.548, P.660, was 30, 48, 53, respectively ... Therefore, the scores indicating all of them achieved standard of diagnosing autism. (Clinical features of MECP2 mutation carriers)

From the results of Autism Behavior Checklist (ABC), the score of P.138, P.548, P.660, was 158, 245, and 195, respectively ... all of them were also above diagnostic score of autism. (Clinical features of MECP2 mutation carriers)
In CRF, P.138 matched all items of social and language ... just satisfied one item of stereotyped behavior. (Clinical features of MECP2 mutation carriers)
It is worth noting that all of them were excluded in the diagnosis of RTT. (Clinical features of MECP2 mutation carriers)
None of the three patients have familial history of psychiatric disorders or neuropathy. (Clinical features of MECP2 mutation carriers)
ASD symptoms of P.138 (female) were onset at age 3 and diagnosed at age 5. ... she spoke first word at 7 months, started walking by herself at 13 months. (Developmental history and family background)

We found p.T1394S (c.4180A>T) of NRXN1 and p.C1855Y (c.5564G>A) of CACNA1C on patient 138 (P.138) ... all the heterozygotes were inherited from unaffected fathers according to data from Sanger sequencing. (Results)
p.P152L locates on exon 2, MBD. (Fig. 1 legend)

cases.description: The last novel deletion 1124del53 was identified in a normocephalic RTT patient. At present the patient is 4 years old. She has an ataxic gait, abnormal breathing, autism and no language. She has never had epileptic seizures. Interestingly, she has no regression and purposeful hand use was preserved. The 1124del53 mutation is predicted to result in the premature truncation of the MeCP2 protein at the newly created amino acid residue 386.

title: Transcriptome and Genome Analysis Uncovers a DMD Structural Variant
author: Folland C, et al.

cases.description: The proband had a typical DMD clinical presentation, autism spectrum disorder (ASD), and dystrophinopathy on muscle biopsy.
cases.family_history: There was no relevant family history.
cases.notes: Single proband case report with DMD paracentric inversion and a DIP2B 5' UTR CGG repeat expansion. Authors note uncertainty regarding the clinical significance of the DIP2B expansion; blood methylation of the expanded allele was not increased. Results section states IQ and language within normal limits despite abstract/intro mention of mild intellectual disability. File reference: Main text: Abstract; Results; Discussion; Figure 3B.
quotes: Results: "The proband had a typical DMD clinical presentation with delayed motor development; he first walked at 18 -20 months of age... He had ASD with poor socialization at school, no friends, and engaged in solo play. His IQ and language were within normal limits."
Results: "There was no relevant family history."
Results: "Skeletal muscle immunoperoxidase staining revealed a complete absence of dystrophin (Figure 1, A and B), consistent with dystrophinopathy."
Results: "Genomic SRS identified a 216 kb paracentric inversion (NC_000023.11:g.33162217-33378800) overlapping 2 DMD promoters."
Results: "ExpansionHunter indicated an expansion of 109 CGG repeats within the 5′ UTR of DIP2B."

Results/Figure 3B: "Targeted LRS confirmed the presence of the large inversion spanning the promoters of Dp427c and Dp427m and the repeat expansion in DIP2B... A heterozygous expansion (270 × CGG) was detected in the patient but absent in healthy controls (n = 10)."
Discussion: "DMD can be associated with cognitive involvement, including autism spectrum disorders."
Discussion: "There was no evidence of hypermethylation on the expanded haplotype, which was predominantly unmethylated at the DIP2B promoter in whole blood."

phenotypic_evidence.core_asd_symptoms: Poor socialization at school; no friends; engaged in solo play.
phenotypic_evidence.cognitive_assessment_results: IQ and language within normal limits.
phenotypic_evidence.cognitive_ability_cautionary_comment: Abstract/intro mentions mild intellectual disability, but Results state IQ and language within normal limits.
phenotypic_evidence.developmental_milestones: First walked at 18–20 months; could walk fast but never ran; used Gowers' maneuver; frequent falls; fatigue.
phenotypic_evidence.comorbidities: Duchenne muscular dystrophy; dystrophinopathy
phenotypic_evidence.phenotypes: Delayed motor development; frequent falls; fatigability; Gowers' maneuver

variant.sequencing_method: Whole genome sequencing with targeted long-read sequencing
variant.sequencing_method_details: Short-read genome sequencing (SRS) detected a 216 kb paracentric inversion; muscle RNA-seq guided detection; targeted Oxford Nanopore long-read sequencing (LRS) confirmed inversion and sized DIP2B repeat expansion.
variant.variant_description: Short-read genome sequencing and muscle RNA-seq guided detection of a 216 kb paracentric inversion at DMD (NC_000023.11:g.33162217-33378800) disrupting promoters of Dp427c and Dp427m. STR analysis suggested DIP2B 5′ UTR CGG expansion (~109 CGG by ExpansionHunter), confirmed and sized by targeted nanopore long-read sequencing at ~270 × CGG; expansion was heterozygous and lacked promoter hypermethylation in blood.
variant.impact: Complete absence of dystrophin on muscle immunostaining; DMD underexpression (Z = -7.43); DIP2B overexpression (Z = 6.14); no hypermethylation of the expanded DIP2B allele in blood.

cases.score_rationale: Variant: other (unknown) | Initial score: 0.1 (range: 0-0.1) | Genotypic downgrades: Limited sequencing method (whole genome sequencing with targeted long-read sequencing): -0.5 | Final quantized score: 0.0

title: Phenotypic and Genotypic Variability in Four Males With MECP2 Gene Sequence Aberrations Including a Novel Deletion
author: Psoni S, et al.

cases.description: DNA sequencing in patient 1 revealed a c.316 C>T (p.R106W) missense change in exon 3 within the MBD; the chromatogram showed two peaks indicating somatic mosaicism. Mother tested normal. Clinically, he developed autistic features (monotonous playing, stereotyped and clumsy hand movements, social withdrawal) with regression of speech; later hyperactivity and attention-deficit disorder were noted.
cases.age: 11 y at genetics evaluation; 14 y follow-up
cases.family_history: Parents were nonconsanguineous and of normal intelligence; maternal DNA normal sequence (no MECP2 variant detected).
cases.notes: Somatic mosaicism supported by two peaks at the variant site in leukocyte DNA and absence in hair roots; extra X chromosome excluded by karyotype. Discussion section also lists c.916 C>T for R106W, likely a typographical discrepancy.
quotes: “The boy was reported to develop normally until the age of 18 mo when he began to display some autistic features such as monotonous playing, stereotyped and clumsy hand movements, and social withdrawal. Regression of acquired skills such as speech development became gradually apparent.” (Patients and Methods: Patient 1)
“He was hyperactive and presented disruptive behavior and attention-deficit disorder.” (Patients and Methods: Patient 1)

“DNA sequencing in patient 1 revealed a substitution of a cytosine by thymidine at position 316 in exon 3, predicted to result in an arginine to tryptophane amino acid change in the MBD at the position 106 of the MeCP2 protein (R106W) … the sequencing chromatogram showed two nucleotide peaks at the variant base position, suggesting the existence of two cell lines and thus a possible somatic mosaicism.” (Results)
“the mother was also tested, revealing a normal sequence.” (Results)
“An extra X chromosome was excluded by chromosomal analysis, but the results of sequencing analysis of leukocyte DNA strongly supported the evidence of somatic mosaicism.” (Discussion)
“Patient 1 exhibited the R106W (c.916 C > T) missense mutation, among the eight most common mutations in the MECP2 gene …” (Discussion)

phenotypic_evidence.core_asd_symptoms: Autistic features including monotonous playing, stereotyped and clumsy hand movements, social withdrawal; regression of speech.
phenotypic_evidence.developmental_milestones: Normal development until 18 months, then regression of acquired skills including speech.
phenotypic_evidence.comorbidities: Mental retardation; hyperactivity; attention-deficit disorder; obesity; no seizures; recurrent otitis media and urinary tract infections.

variant.variant_description: Sequencing showed two nucleotide peaks at the variant site consistent with somatic mosaicism in leukocytes; no variant detected in hair roots; maternal DNA normal. Discussion also notes c.916C>T for R106W, likely a typographical discrepancy.
variant.impact: Classic RTT-associated mutation reported to impair MeCP2 function; somatic mosaicism likely attenuates phenotype in this male.
variant.segregation_data: Mother tested negative for the variant (normal MECP2 sequence); hair roots of patient showed normal sequence; karyotype 46,XY (no extra X).

cases.score_rationale: Variant: missense (mosaic) | Initial score: 0.5 (range: 0-2.5) | Phenotype adjustment (medium confidence): -0.35 | Pre-quantization score: 0.15 | Final quantized score: 0.15

title: SHANK1 Deletions in Males with Autism Spectrum Disorder
author: Sato D, et al.

cases.description: III-5 (male) ASD e : Asperger disorder (ADI-R and ADOS-4) and anxiety
cases.family_history: Multigenerational family with SHANK1 deletion; also present in males I-1, IV-1, IV-3 and females II-4, III-2.
cases.notes: Deletion validated by breakpoint sequencing; co-segregating PCDHGA11 Tyr313* nonsense variant on 5q31.3 reported in family 1. Sources: Main text (Results); Table 1; Figure 1; Figure 2.
quotes: We initially identified a hemizygous microdeletion in chromosomal region 19q13.33 in ASD proband III-5 from the Canadian cohort (see family 1 in Table 1 and Figure 1).
The deletion, which was determined to be 63.8 kb, eliminated exons 1-20 of SHANK1 and the neighboring CLEC11A (MIM 604713)
The accurate coordinates for family 1 were mapped by sequencing across the breakpoints and are Chr 19: 55,872,189-55,935,995 (hg18).
Subsequent genotyping in family 1 revealed that the deletion was also present in males I-1, IV-1, and IV-3 as well as in females II-4 and III-2 (Figure 1).
III-5 (male) ASD e : Asperger disorder (ADI-R and ADOS-4) and anxiety
Leiter-R: brief NVIQ = 83 (13th %ile; LA)
OWLS: TL = 68 (2nd %ile; delay)
VABS-I: ABC = 52 (< 1st %ile), COM = 43 (< 1st %ile), DLS = 63 (1st %ile), and SOC = 65 (1st %ile); he currently takes olanzapine and paroxetine for the anxiety disorder

When III-5 was 25 years old, the ADI-R and ADOS diagnosed him with autism according to the cut-offs, but his current best-estimate diagnoses are that of Asperger disorder ... and a separate anxiety disorder; ... now, at age 32, he lives independently and works in a sheltered workshop.

phenotypic_evidence.developmental_milestones: Single words at 24 months; phrases by 36 months; parents first concerned at 12–24 months
phenotypic_evidence.comorbidities: Anxiety disorder; treated with olanzapine and paroxetine
phenotypic_evidence.phenotypes: Poor eye contact; lacked joint attention and empathy; repetitive play and speech in early childhood

cases.description: II-1 (male) ASD with higher functioning (ADI-R; CARS: mild autism)
cases.family_history: Younger maternal half-sister (F2-II-3) with autism and mild ID; she does not carry the SHANK1 deletion.
cases.notes: Sources: Main text (Results); Table 1; Figure 2; Figure S1.
quotes: In separate microarray experiments examining 456 ASDaffected individuals from Europe, we identified a 63.4 kb hemizygous CNV in individual F2-II-1 from family 2; this CNV deleted the last three exons of SHANK1 and the entire centromeric synaptotagmin-3 (SYT3 [MIM 600327]) gene

Haplotype analysis revealed that the deletion resided on the chromosome originating from the mother (who was shown to carry two copies of SHANK1), so it was presumed to be a de novo event (Figure S1).
The de novo deletion of family 2 was detected by microarray and has coordinates Chr 19: 55,808,307-55,871,709 (hg18).
II-1 (male) ASD with higher functioning (ADI-R; CARS: mild autism)
WISC: FSIQ = 115 (84th %ile; HA), VIQ = 120 (93rd %ile), and PIQ = 100 (50th %ile) (VIQ > PIQ)
PET: mild hyperfusion temporal left

He did not babble, made no eye contact, and refused to be touched. ... He developed a formal, pedantic style of speech with abnormal prosody. ... He repeated routines and rituals and accumulated facts on certain subjects such as astronomy. ... Lately, he has had periods of depression.

title: Two affected boys in a Rett syndrome family
author: Villard L, et al.

cases.description: Patient III-3 is a 17-year-old girl with typical Rett syndrome. She fulfilled eight of the nine international criteria: normal pregnancy and birth, normal early development, normal head circumference at birth, later slowing of head growth, loss of purposeful hand skills between ages 6 and 30 months associated with deterioration in communication and social withdrawal, development of severely impaired expressive and receptive language and presence of apparent severe psychomotor retardation, stereotypic hand movements, and diagnosis tentative until age 2 to 5 years.
cases.family_history: Two brothers (III-2 and III-4) died in infancy from severe encephalopathy; mother (II-2) is a carrier of the T158M mutation with completely skewed X-chromosome inactivation; mutation absent in other tested relatives (I-1, I-2, II-1, III-1).
cases.notes: Missing Rett criterion: absence of gait apraxia and truncal apraxia/ataxia between ages 1 and 4 years. No epilepsy or vasomotor disturbances of the lower limbs reported.
quotes: “Patient III-3 is a 17-year-old girl with typical Rett syndrome.” (Results – Clinical findings)

“She fulfilled eight of the nine international criteria: normal pregnancy and birth, normal early development, normal head circumference at birth, later slowing of head growth, loss of purposeful hand skills between ages 6 and 30 months associated with deterioration in communication and social withdrawal, development of severely impaired expressive and receptive language and presence of apparent severe psychomotor retardation, stereotypic hand movements, and diagnosis tentative until age 2 to 5 years.” (Results – Clinical findings)

“Sequencing revealed the presence of a mutation (C to T nucleotide change resulting in the T158M amino acid change) both in the mother's and in her affected daughter's DNA.” (Results – Identification of a mutation in MECP2)
“Abnormal restriction fragments (arrows) indicate that individuals II-2 and III-3 are carriers of the mutation.” (Figure 2A legend)
“The mother of the patients is a carrier of the T158M mutation.” (Abstract)
“mutation was not found in the DNA of the other members of the family (I-1, I-2, II-1, and III-1).” (Results – Identification of a mutation in MECP2)

“Rett patients stop developing at about 1 year old, and have a series of clinical signs indicative of a neurodegenerative process: arrest of brain development, regression of acquisitions, and behavioral troubles (stereotypic hand movement, autism).” (Introduction)

phenotypic_evidence.core_asd_symptoms: Stereotypic hand movements; deterioration in communication; social withdrawal; severely impaired expressive and receptive language.
phenotypic_evidence.developmental_milestones: Later slowing of head growth; loss of purposeful hand skills between 6 and 30 months; diagnosis tentative until age 2–5 years.
phenotypic_evidence.comorbidities: No epilepsy; no vasomotor disturbances of the lower limbs.
phenotypic_evidence.phenotypes: Apparent severe psychomotor retardation.

variant.sequencing_method_details: SSCP screening followed by Sanger sequencing and NlaIII restriction digest confirmation
variant.variant_description: Missense substitution T158M in MECP2; detected by SSCP, sequencing, and restriction digest (NlaIII).
variant.segregation_data: Carrier mother (II-2) and affected daughter (III-3) positive for T158M by sequencing/restriction analysis; mutation absent in I-1, I-2, II-1, III-1; brother III-2 also carried T158M; origin traced to grandpaternal X chromosome.

cases.score_rationale: Variant: missense (maternal) | Initial score: 0.1 (range: 0-0.1) | Genotypic downgrades: Very small/exclusive gene panel - score set to 0 | Final quantized score: 0.0

title: Autistic-like Behaviors Associated with a Novel Non-Canonical Splice-Site DDX3X Variant: A Case Report of a Rare Clinical Syndrome
author: Stefaniak U, et al.

cases.description: We report a 7 year old nonverbal female with a likely novel de novo pathogenic heterozygous variant in the DDX3X gene affecting the non-canonical splice-site in the intron 1 (NM_001356:c.45+12G>A). (Abstract)
cases.family_history: No genetic conditions in the family; no children with IDD beyond the second generation; no epilepsy.
cases.notes: Paternal DNA not available. DDX3X variant classified as VUS at time of testing; in-silico suggests splicing impact. Additional HSD17B4 VUS were in cis and maternally inherited; Perrault syndrome ruled out. First reported Polish individual with DDX3X-associated disorder in this paper.
quotes: We report a 7 year old nonverbal female with a likely novel de novo pathogenic heterozygous variant in the DDX3X gene affecting the non-canonical splice-site in the intron 1 (NM_001356:c.45+12G>A). (Abstract)
The patient initially received a diagnosis of ASD as the result of a psychological test at three years of age, (Discussion)
a diagnosis of autism spectrum disorder (ASD) (Abstract)

In an evaluation at three years of age revealed behaviors related to ASD, such as stereotypy, problems with imitation movements that suggested problems with mirror neurons, and dysfunction with sensory processing: tactile defensiveness, lack of speech, and occasional sleep disturbances. (Materials and Methods)
GENE DDX3X ... TRANSCRIPT NM_001356.4 ... NOMENCLATURE c.45+12G>A ... CONSEQUENCE intron_variant ... GENOTYPE HET ... CLASSIFICATION Variant of uncertain significance (Table 2)

the variant in DDX3X previously not reported in population databases [13] was found to be absent in the maternal sample and hence likely a de novo event. Even though the paternal sample was not available for co-segregation studies, (Materials and Methods following Table 2)
At the age of four, she was diagnosed with celiac disease, which confirmed the cause of her severe constipation in earlier years. (Materials and Methods)

The patient's brain Magnetic Resonance Imaging MRI examination did not reveal any abnormalities ... an arachnoid cyst shaping the front surface of the temporal lobe had been found on the right side ... a slight delayed myelination of white matter (Materials and Methods/Figures 1–4)

As can be seen in Table 3, the patient in this study scored v-scale scores for the following skills: 1 for receptive (low), 2 for expressive (low), 4 for written (low), 9 for personal (low), 6 for domestic (low), 6 for community (low), 6 for interpersonal (low), 6 for play and leisure (low), 5 for coping (low), 13 for gross motor (moderately low), and 8 for fine motor skills (low). (Results/Table 3)
This is the first study to report a case of a Polish individual with a DDX3X -associated disorder. (Discussion)

The patient, who is currently 7 years old, was the first-born child. ... there were no genetic conditions in this family, children with IDD beyond the second generation, or a diagnosis of epilepsy. (Materials and Methods)

phenotypic_evidence.core_asd_symptoms: Nonverbal/lack of speech; stereotypy; limited and repetitive patterns of behavior; problems with imitation movements; social difficulties/unresponsive to environmental cues; sleep disturbance; sensory processing dysfunction (tactile defensiveness).
phenotypic_evidence.assessment_tools_used: Vineland Adaptive Behavior Scales, Third Edition (Vineland-III) Comprehensive Parent/Caregiver Form; ICF-CY (motor function assessment)
phenotypic_evidence.cognitive_assessment_results: Vineland-III: Adaptive Behavior Composite 49 (Low); Communication Standard Score 27 (Low); Daily Living 57 (Low); Socialization 46 (Low); Motor 74 (Moderately Low).
phenotypic_evidence.cognitive_ability_cautionary_comment: No formal IQ reported; Vineland-III indicates low adaptive functioning. Insufficient information to classify ID severity.
phenotypic_evidence.developmental_milestones: Delayed psychomotor development; speech delay; motor skills measurable via ICF-CY (able to walk stairs, jump, kick a ball).
phenotypic_evidence.comorbidities: Celiac disease; right temporal arachnoid cyst; slight delayed myelination; spinal asymmetry (scoliometer 10° thoracolumbar, 5° cervicothoracic); sleep disturbance; high pain threshold; temperature dysregulation.
phenotypic_evidence.phenotypes: Nonverbal; stereotypies; sensory processing dysfunction (tactile defensiveness); sleep disturbance; high pain threshold; temperature dysregulation; right temporal arachnoid cyst; delayed myelination; spinal asymmetry.

variant.region: intron (non-canonical splice site, +12 from donor of exon 1)
variant.variant_description: Novel deep intronic (+12) DDX3X variant near exon 1 predicted to alter RNA-recognition motifs of SR proteins (ESE-Finder v3.0). Classified as VUS at testing. Additional HSD17B4 missense variants (c.11C>G p.Pro4Arg; c.482A>G p.Glu161Gly) were benign/tolerated in silico and in cis from mother.
variant.impact: In-silico analyses suggest splicing impact; likely deleterious; absent in gnomAD.
variant.splice_info: Non-canonical splice-site (+12); predicted to alter SR protein binding (ESE-Finder v3.0).
variant.segregation_data: Absent in maternal DNA; paternal sample not available; likely de novo. Two HSD17B4 variants maternally inherited in cis.

cases.score_rationale: Variant: predicted_null (de_novo) | Splice type: canonical | Initial score: 2.0 (range: 0-2.5) | Phenotype adjustment (medium confidence): -0.5 | Genotypic downgrades: Sequencing method not provided: -0.5 | Final quantized score: 1.0

title: Biophysical classification of a CACNA1D de novo mutation as a high-risk mutation for a severe neurodevelopmental disorder
author: Hofer NT, et al.

cases.description: The CACNA1D variant (chr3: 53757881 C>T, human reference genome hg19) was predicted to cause a p.Ser652Leu (S652L) mutation (reference sequence NM_001128839). The patients (DECIPHER database individuals #262954 and #262956; decipher.sanger.ac.uk) are male monozygotic twins, thirteen years old at present, and both harbor one copy of the mutation. Their clinical phenotype has been updated recently. It manifests as a severe neurodevelopmental phenotype with delayed speech and language development and a global developmental delay. Both individuals show self-injurious behaviors and have been diagnosed with ASD two years ago.
cases.family_history: Monozygotic twins; described as de novo in the proband; parents unaffected.

quotes: Patient 2 had had a presumed de novo frameshift deletion, MECP2 c.771_814del (p.Glu258Glyfs*58).

Despite having many features associated with RTT and a diagnosis of RTT by her treating clinicians, she did not meet the formal diagnostic criteria due to developmental plateau but not regression.

title: Case Report: Lennox -Gastaut Epileptic Encephalopathy Responsive to Cannabidiol Treatment Associated With a Novel de novo Mosaic SHANK1 Variant
author: Paprocka J, et al.

cases.description: An 11-year-old boy with Lennox-Gastaut syndrome, global developmental delay, and autistic features without congenital defects or facial dysmorphic features and negative family history for neurodevelopmental disorders was referred for WES. On psychological evaluation, moderate intellectual disability and autism spectrum disorder were found.
cases.family_history: negative family history for neurodevelopmental disorders
cases.notes: Lennox-Gastaut epileptic encephalopathy with polymorphic seizures beginning at age 2; refractory epilepsy markedly responsive to cannabidiol with >4 years seizure freedom; generalized hypotonia; normal MRI and metabolic workup; head circumference 52 cm (10th centile).
quotes: An 11-year-old boy with Lennox -Gastaut syndrome, global developmental delay, and autistic features without congenital defects or facial dysmorphic features and negative family history for neurodevelopmental disorders was referred for WES.
On psychological evaluation, moderate intellectual disability and autism spectrum disorder were found.

A heterozygous variant in the SHANK1 gene [hg38; chr19: g.050716358-C > G, NM\_016148.5: c.376 /equals /G > C, p.(Gly126Arg)] ( Figure 2 ) was found on 21% of all reads (N /equals 113/X), suggesting it was mosaic.
Co-segregation studies using ADS con /uniFB01 rmed the variant as de novo and showed mosaicism at the level of 19% of reads (N /equals 7995).
The analysis of the WES data and variant prioritization were performed, as previously described (Ploski et al., 2014), except that the Hg38 human genome version was used for alignment.
The first epileptic seizures appeared at the age of 2 years.
Polymorphic seizures (tonic -clonic, atonic, myoclonic, and absence seizures) required numerous changes of therapy.
After cannabidiol administration, the epileptic seizures stopped, and the patient has been seizure-free for > 4 years now.
The most recent neurological examination showed the head circumference of 52 cm (10th centile) and generalized hypotonia with preserved tendon re /uniFB02 exes.

The SHANK1 heterozygous p.Gly126Arg variant found in our patient is a previously unreported missense mutation which occurred de novo , most likely as an early postzygotic event present in approximately 40% of mature cells.

phenotypic_evidence.developmental_milestones: Global developmental delay; at age 2 not able to walk independently or communicate verbally; later counts to 10, knows a few letters, follows simple commands.
phenotypic_evidence.comorbidities: Lennox-Gastaut syndrome; refractory epilepsy (seizure freedom on cannabidiol); generalized hypotonia; status epilepticus (twice, responsive to IV benzodiazepines); head circumference 52 cm (10th centile); EEG: generalized paroxysmal changes with slow spike-and-wave complexes (<3 Hz)

variant.sequencing_method: whole exome sequencing (WES) with confirmation by amplicon deep sequencing (ADS)
variant.sequencing_method_details: WES aligned to hg38; variant detected at ~21% of reads; ADS confirmed de novo mosaicism at ~19% (N=7995 reads).
variant.variant_description: Heterozygous mosaic missense variant detected at 21% of reads by WES; confirmed de novo and mosaic at 19% by ADS; located in a highly conserved region of the SHANK1 N-terminal domain.
variant.impact: Absent from population databases; in silico analyses indicate deleterious effect on protein structure and interactions.
variant.segregation_data: De novo by ADS; mosaic in blood (~21% WES; 19% ADS); parents tested negative.

cases.description: We present a 21-year-old male with severe mental retardation, spastic tetraplegia, dystonia, apraxia and neurogenic scoliosis. A history of early hypotonia evolving into severe spasticity, slowing of head growth, breathing irregularities and good visual interactive behaviour were highly suggestive of Rett syndrome.
cases.family_history: De novo mutation.
cases.notes: Present case labeled as 'male Rett variant' in Table 1. Source locations: Case report; Results; Table 1.
quotes: We present a 21-year-old male with severe mental retardation, spastic tetraplegia, dystonia, apraxia and neurogenic scoliosis.
A history of early hypotonia evolving into severe spasticity, slowing of head growth, breathing irregularities and good visual interactive behaviour were highly suggestive of Rett syndrome.

DNA sequence analysis of the MECP 2 gene of our index patient revealed the presence of a cytosine to thymidine nucleotide substitution at position 674 of the coding region. This nucleotide substitution (C674T) leads to a proline to leucine amino acid change in the transcriptional repression domain (TRD) at position 225 of the MeCP2 protein (P225L).
Consequently, our data indicate that the observed C674T substitution in our patient has arisen de novo and is not to be found in the general population.
25 | 46,XY | P225L (C674T) | TRD | 21 years | Severe MR ± neurologic features, male Rett variant | De novo mutation | Present case

Shortly thereafter he began to show axial hypotonia and a marked head lag. His psychomotor development became severely retarded. He never learned to sit alone nor to walk, and lost his ability to stand with support at the age of 2 years.
There was no speech development.
Around 3.5 months of age, his mother noticed 'a change' in making contact and in behaviour towards her.
He had good visual contact, recognizing his parents and caregivers both visually and vocally, but seemed to be very reserved towards strangers.
Sometimes he became extremely pale and had shallow breathing interrupted by short apnoeic periods.

phenotypic_evidence.core_asd_symptoms: Regression in early infancy; no speech development; altered social contact noted by mother; reserved towards strangers.
phenotypic_evidence.developmental_milestones: Apparently normal very early infantile development; regression starting around 3.5 months; severe psychomotor delay; loss of motor abilities; no speech development.
phenotypic_evidence.comorbidities: spastic tetraplegia; dystonia; apraxia; neurogenic scoliosis; epilepsy (infancy to 7 years); breathing irregularities; kyphoscoliosis; joint contractures; hip dislocation

variant.variant_description: De novo P225L (C674T) in TRD; present case with phenotype resembling Rett syndrome.
variant.impact: missense change at conserved residue in transcriptional repression domain
variant.segregation_data: De novo mutation confirmed by sequencing and SSCP; mother and brothers negative.

title: Genomic diagnosis for children with intellectual disability and/or developmental delay
author: Bowling KM, et al.

cases.description: As an example, we sequenced an affected 14-yearold girl (00003-C, Additional file 2: Table S1) who presented with severe ID, seizures, speech delay, autism, and stereotypic behaviors. WES revealed an SNV within the splice acceptor site of intron 2 in MECP2 (c.27-6C > G, MIM:312750), identical to a previously observed de novo variant in a 5-year-old girl with several features of Rett syndrome, but who lacked deceleration of head growth and exhibited typical growth development.
cases.cohort_name: Genomic diagnosis for children with intellectual disability and/or developmental delay (HudsonAlpha CSER DD/ID cohort)
cases.notes: Identical variant previously reported de novo in Rett; inheritance not explicitly stated for this proband. Source: Main text - Results: Alternative mechanisms of disease
quotes: [Results - Alternative mechanisms of disease] "we sequenced an affected 14-yearold girl (00003-C, Additional file 2: Table S1) who presented with severe ID, seizures, speech delay, autism, and stereotypic behaviors."
[Results - Alternative mechanisms of disease] "WES revealed an SNV within the splice acceptor site of intron 2 in MECP2 (c.27-6C > G, MIM:312750)"
[Results - Alternative mechanisms of disease] "the variant produces a cryptic splice acceptor site that adds five nucleotides to the messenger RNA resulting in a frameshift (p.R9fs24X)"

phenotypic_evidence.core_asd_symptoms: Autism with stereotypic behaviors and speech delay.
phenotypic_evidence.cognitive_ability_cautionary_comment: Severe ID with limited ASD diagnostic detail; confidence downgraded (indicator E only).
phenotypic_evidence.developmental_milestones: Speech delay reported.
phenotypic_evidence.comorbidities: Severe intellectual disability and seizures; Rett-like features.
phenotypic_evidence.phenotypes: Autism, stereotypic behaviors, speech delay, seizures, severe ID, Rett-like features.

variant.sequencing_method_details: RNA studies (qPCR/Sanger) demonstrated cryptic acceptor usage causing frameshift (p.R9fs24X).
variant.region: Splice acceptor region of intron 2 (-6 position).
variant.variant_description: Non-canonical acceptor variant activating a cryptic acceptor; +5 nt insertion into mRNA causing frameshift and truncation.
variant.splice_info: Cryptic splice acceptor used; +5 nt insertion into mRNA causes frameshift.
variant.segregation_data: Identical variant previously observed de novo in another patient; inheritance for this proband not stated.

title: Dystrophin genetic variants and autism
author: Passos-Bueno MR, et al.

cases.description: Patient P1 was referred to our center at the age of 15 because of ASD... ADOS-2 (23 points) and CARS (35 points) results were compatible with a mild to moderate ASD diagnosis. An outof-frame deletion encompassing exons 2-9 in a currently 17 year old male (P1; F1).
cases.cohort_name: Family 1 (discordant monozygotic twins; ASD WES cohort)
cases.family_history: Monozygotic twin (P2) does not have ASD; both twins carry the DMD deletion; mother is a carrier.
cases.notes: Tiptoe walking and developmental regression reported at 2.5 years. No other pathogenic ASD variant of major effect identified on WES.
quotes: Patient P1 was referred to our center at the age of 15 because of ASD.
ADOS-2 (23 points) and CARS (35 points) results were compatible with a mild to moderate ASD diagnosis.
an outof-frame deletion encompassing exons 2-9 in a currently 17 year old male (P1; F1)
The 2-9 dystrophin deletion... was validated by MLPA (multiplex ligation-dependent probe amplification) in both twin siblings... the mother is a carrier of the dystrophin pathogenic variant.
A neurologist established ASD diagnosis when he was 7 years old.

phenotypic_evidence.core_asd_symptoms: Speech, motor and behavioral regression at 2.5 years; echolalia.
phenotypic_evidence.cognitive_assessment_results: Attended special school; can read and write. ADOS-2 total 23; CARS total 35.
phenotypic_evidence.developmental_milestones: Normal motor and speech development until 2.5 years; regression; resumed two-word phrases by age 4 with intervention.
phenotypic_evidence.phenotypes: Tiptoe walking; developmental regression at 2.5 years.

variant.sequencing_method_details: WES-based CNV calling; validated by MLPA.
variant.variant_description: CNV detected by WES CNV analysis and validated by MLPA.
variant.impact: Predicted to disrupt only the long Dp427 isoforms.
variant.segregation_data: Deletion detected in both twins; mother is carrier (MLPA-validated).

cases.score_rationale: Variant: predicted_null (maternal) | Initial score: 1.0 (range: 0-2.0) | Phenotype adjustment (medium confidence): -0.25 | Final quantized score: 0.75

cases.description: P3 was referred to our center for genetic counseling due to an ASD diagnosis when he was five years old... WES revealed the stop gain variant in dystrophin, NM_000109:c.11017A > T (p.Arg3673*), inherited from his mother.
cases.family_history: Mother carrier of DMD variant.
cases.notes: High-functioning ASD; no muscular dystrophy signs at age 5. MRI showed arachnoid cyst (age four).
quotes: P3 was referred to our center for genetic counseling due to an ASD diagnosis when he was five years old.
WES revealed the above mentioned stop gain variant in dystrophin, NM_000109:c.11017A > T (p.Arg3673*), inherited from his mother.
After evaluation by a neurologist, he was diagnosed with high functioning ASD.
presented stereotypes, echolalia, no interaction at school, and absent eye contact.
This variant is absent in males in the 1000Genomes, AbrAOM and GnomAD databases... previously described in ClinVar (rs1477369230) as VUS in one DMD individual.

phenotypic_evidence.core_asd_symptoms: Stereotypes, echolalia, poor social interaction, absent eye contact.
phenotypic_evidence.developmental_milestones: Learned to read at age 3.

variant.variant_description: Stop-gain near 3′ end; potential NMD and isoform-specific effects uncertain.
variant.impact: May affect Dp427, Dp140, and Dp71 isoforms.
variant.segregation_data: Inherited from mother.

cases.score_rationale: Variant: predicted_null (maternal) | Initial score: 1.0 (range: 0-2.0) | Phenotype adjustment (medium confidence): -0.25 | Final quantized score: 0.75

cases.description: High serum CK levels and muscle biopsy in P4 were compatible with dystrophinopathy, which was confirmed via molecular testing, NM_000109: c.64_69+16del... (p.Lys22_Ser23del). At age six, CARS 32.5, compatible with ASD diagnosis; Vineland 44.
cases.family_history: Triplet; brothers P5 (DMD+ASD) and P6 (ASD without DMD).
cases.notes: Conceived by IVF. Walked at 18 months with frequent falls; global hypotonia at 3 years.
quotes: High serum CK levels (about 35-40 times increased) and muscle biopsy (dystrophic pattern with dystrophin deficiency, data not shown) in P4 and P5 were compatible with dystrophinopathy, which was confirmed via molecular testing, NM_000109: c.64_69 + 16delTCT AAG GTA AGA ATG GTT TGTT (p.lys22_Ser23del).

The two DMD boys, P4 and P5, at the age of six were scored 32.5 and 31, respectively by the CARS autism scale, which is compatible with ASD diagnosis. Vineland scores were 44 and 45, respectively, indicating low adaptive behavior.
None of the three brothers had developed verbal language until three years-old nor any nonverbal language to interact. They also typically displayed repetitive and stereotyped behavior.

phenotypic_evidence.core_asd_symptoms: Lack of verbal and nonverbal language by age 3; repetitive and stereotyped behavior.
phenotypic_evidence.developmental_milestones: Walking at 18 months with frequent falls; global hypotonia by age 3.
phenotypic_evidence.comorbidities: Duchenne muscular dystrophy; intellectual disability.

variant.variant_description: Small deletion spanning coding and intronic sequence with in-frame protein deletion.
variant.impact: Possibly disrupts all full-length Dp427 isoforms but not shorter isoforms.
variant.segregation_data: Not reported.

cases.description: Molecular tests revealed the dystrophin stop gain variant: NM_000109:c.1591C > T (p.Arg531*). Both siblings were diagnosed with ASD when they were 4.5 years old by a neurologist; CARS = 39 (at 17 years).
cases.family_history: Monozygotic twin (P8) similarly affected.
cases.notes: Stopped walking at 9 years; multiple medical comorbidities listed in Table 2. WES in one twin identified a de novo EBF3 p.R206* variant consistent with HADDS.
quotes: Molecular tests revealed the dystrophin stop gain variant: NM_000109:c.1591C > T (p.Arg531*), compatible with a molecular diagnosis of DMD.
In addition to motor and speech impairments, they also presented behavior and social problems, being both diagnosed with ASD when they were 4 years and 6 months old by a neurologist.
CARS evaluation for both twins showed results compatible with ASD diagnosis (CARS = 39 for both, performed when they were 17 years old).
WES analysis of one of the twins and their parents... revealed a heterozygous LoF pathogenic variant following ACMG criteria in EBF3: NM_001005463:c.616C > T (p.R206*).

phenotypic_evidence.core_asd_symptoms: Behavior and social problems; speech delay; echolalia.
phenotypic_evidence.developmental_milestones: First words at ~12 months; walked at 18 months; delayed motor and speech development.
phenotypic_evidence.comorbidities: Duchenne muscular dystrophy; myopia; cataract; vitamin D deficiency; dyslipidemia; sinus tachycardia; presumed osteoporosis; wheelchair since 9 years.

variant.variant_description: Stop-gain in DMD; additional de novo EBF3 stop-gain (NM_001005463:c.616C>T; p.R206*) associated with HADDS.
variant.impact: Predicted to disrupt Dp427 isoforms; shorter isoforms not affected.
variant.segregation_data: Monozygotic twin pair; DMD variant present in both twins; EBF3 p.R206* de novo identified in one twin and presumed in co-twin.

cases.score_rationale: Variant: predicted_null (unknown) | Initial score: 1.5 (range: 0-2.0) | Genotypic downgrades: Sequencing method not provided: -0.5 | Final quantized score: 1.0
