title: The spectrum of phenotypes in females with Rett Syndrome
author: Huppke P, et al.

cases.description: Case 1 (congenital RTT). She had no period of normal development, head control was always poor, never learned to turn, sit or walk; spoke two words at 12 months then lost speech and hand function; severe epilepsy at 10 months; head circumference decelerated to <3rd percentile within first year. Genetic analysis: 1364-1365 C insertion in MECP2.
cases.cohort_name: Rett Syndrome cohort (120 females with MECP2 mutations)
cases.notes: Labeled congenital RTT; severe developmental phenotype with early epilepsy and postnatal microcephaly.
quotes: 2.1.1. Case 1 (congenital RTT)
She had no period of normal development, the head control was always poor and she never learned to turn, sit or walk.
At age 10 months she developed severe epilepsy.
However, at 12 months of age she spoke two words and had some hand function but shortly after lost both abilities.
Her head circumference was normal at birth (35 cm) but decelerated within the first 12 months to below the 3rd percentile.
The genetic analysis revealed a 1364-1365 C insertion in the MECP2 gene.

phenotypic_evidence.core_asd_symptoms: Language regression (loss of spoken words); profound developmental delay consistent with RTT; no explicit social behavior description.
phenotypic_evidence.developmental_milestones: Never learned to turn, sit or walk; spoke two words at 12 months then lost speech and hand function.
phenotypic_evidence.comorbidities: Severe epilepsy starting at 10 months; postnatal microcephaly (<3rd percentile OFC).

variant.variant_description: Insertion reported in MECP2 coding region; exact HGVS c. notation not provided in text.

cases.score_rationale: Variant: other (unknown) | Initial score: 0.1 (range: 0-0.1) | Genotypic downgrades: Sequencing method not provided: -0.5 | Final quantized score: 0.0

cases.description: Case 2 (forme fruste). Normal motor development; language advanced by 24 months; at 33 months refused body contact, lost manual skills, reduced speech to single words; six months later she lost her autistic behaviour and showed progress. At 9 years: normal growth (OFC ~90th percentile), good gross motor function, some hand function, occasional hand stereotypies, notable speech ability. Genetic analysis: R306C-. T mutation in MECP2.
cases.cohort_name: Rett Syndrome cohort (120 females with MECP2 mutations)
cases.family_history: Patient II has a normal family history
cases.notes: Mild RTT (forme fruste) with transient autistic behavior and preserved speech.
quotes: 2.1.2. Case 2 (forme fruste)
At 33 months of age the parents noted that she refused body contact, lost manual skills and that she spoke less frequently and only single words.
Six months later she lost her autistic behaviour again and showed developmental progress.
At presentation at age 9 years her height, weight and OFC were within the normal range (90th percentile).
Notable was her speech ability. She spoke three word sentences, answered questions, followed instructions, counted to 20 and sang English songs (her mother language is German).
The genetic analysis revealed a R306C-. T mutation in the MECP2 gene.

phenotypic_evidence.core_asd_symptoms: Autistic behaviour (transient); social contact refusal; language regression to single words with later improvement; occasional hand stereotypies.
phenotypic_evidence.developmental_milestones: Walking at 12 months; speaking 3–4 word sentences by 24 months; regression at 33 months; improved thereafter.
phenotypic_evidence.comorbidities: None noted beyond RTT-related features.

variant.variant_description: Protein-level missense (R306C) reported; nucleotide change not clearly formatted in text.

cases.score_rationale: Variant: missense (unknown) | Initial score: 0.1 (range: 0-0.1) | Genotypic downgrades: Sequencing method not provided: -0.5 | Final quantized score: 0.0

cases.description: Case 3 (electrical status epilepticus during sleep). Initial normal development; slowed without regression; at 7 years: normal gait, good hand function, spoke three words, OFC at 3rd percentile, stereotypic hand movements. Diagnosed as infantile autism at the time. EEG showed ESES; steroids improved EEG only. Genetic analysis: 880-884 deletion in MECP2.
cases.cohort_name: Rett Syndrome cohort (120 females with MECP2 mutations)
cases.family_history: Patient III was born after an uneventful pregnancy into a healthy family.
cases.notes: RTT with ESES and diagnosis of infantile autism.
quotes: 2.1.3. Case 3 (electrical status epilepticus during sleep)
At the time of first presentation at age 7 she had a normal gait, good hand function and spoke three words.
The OFC was in the 3rd percentile and stereotypic hand movements were present.
The diagnosis at the time was infantile autism.
The EEG at age 7 years showed an electrical status epilepticus during sleep (ESES).
The genetic analysis revealed a 880-884 deletion in the MECP2 gene.

phenotypic_evidence.core_asd_symptoms: Infantile autism diagnosis; limited speech (three words); stereotypic hand movements.
phenotypic_evidence.developmental_milestones: Smiled at 3 months; sat at 7 months; stood unsupported at 12 months; walked at age 2 years.
phenotypic_evidence.comorbidities: Electrical status epilepticus during sleep (ESES); borderline microcephaly (OFC 3rd percentile).

variant.variant_description: Deletion reported across nucleotides 880–884 of MECP2; exact HGVS c. notation not provided.

cases.description: Case 4 (precocious puberty). Normal development in first year; spoke two words at 13 months then never spoke again; walked at 28 months; hand function deteriorated and stereotyped hand movements occurred; precocious puberty at 7 years; treated with leuprorelin. Genetic analysis: R168X mutation in MECP2.
cases.cohort_name: Rett Syndrome cohort (120 females with MECP2 mutations)
cases.family_history: Patient IV was the first child of healthy parents.
cases.notes: RTT with precocious puberty; classic language regression and stereotypies.
quotes: 2.1.4. Case 4 (precocious puberty)
After speaking two words at age 13 months she stopped and never spoke again.
At age 28 months she learned to walk. During this time her handfunction deteriorated and stereotyped hand movements occurred.
At age 7 years precocious puberty was noted (stadium B3, PH4 according to Tanner [17]).
She was subsequently treated with leuprorelin (Enantone w Takeda) which stopped further pubertal development.
The genetic analysis revealed an R168X mutation in the MECP2 gene.

phenotypic_evidence.core_asd_symptoms: Language regression (loss of speech); stereotyped hand movements.
phenotypic_evidence.developmental_milestones: Normal early milestones in first year; speech ceased after two words at 13 months; walked at 28 months.
phenotypic_evidence.comorbidities: Precocious puberty (B3, PH4 by Tanner); treated with leuprorelin.

variant.variant_description: Protein-level nonsense variant R168X in MECP2.

title: Rett syndrome from quintuple and triple deletions within the MECP 2 deletion hotspot region
author: Lebo RV, et al.

cases.description: This Caucasian American female, seen at 5 years 7 months, had normal milestones until ~18 months, when language regression, loss of self-care, and autistic behavior appeared. She exhibited repetitive hand-wringing, poor eye contact, aimless wandering, hyperventilation with apnea, tremulousness, hypertonicity (legs), and an abnormal EEG with bilateral central spikes. Genetic testing identified a quintuple deletion in MECP2 exon 4 (five adjacent deletions totaling −65 bp) causing a frameshift after K347 and premature termination after codon 381.
cases.family_history: No parental consanguinity; parents unavailable for segregation testing.
cases.notes: Classic Rett phenotype described; PCR showed both normal and deleted alleles, consistent with heterozygosity. Parents unavailable for mutation testing.
quotes: She was seen at 5 years 7 months and was noted to have achieved normal developmental milestones until about 18 months of age. At that time, language regression was noted... Autistic behavior became apparent and she tended to wander around aimlessly in circles.
Repetitive hand-wringing was seen and hypertonicity was obvious, especially in the legs. An electroencephalogram was abnormal, showing bilateral central spikes.
Propositus 1 had an MECP 2 deletion of five adjacent polynucleotide sequences within a 3' 143-bp exon 4 region (Fig. 1B).

This product was 65 bp shorter following five unequal recombinations that deleted 14, 14, 3, 26, and 8 bp... These recombinations resulted in a gene sequence that is transcribed out of frame after amino acid K347 and is terminated after codon 381...
A small quantity of normal product was visible following PCR amplification (Fig. 2A).
parents of propositus 1 were unavailable.

phenotypic_evidence.core_asd_symptoms: Autistic behavior; Poor eye contact; Repetitive hand-wringing; Aimless wandering; Loss of speech
phenotypic_evidence.developmental_milestones: Normal until ~18 months; regression thereafter (language, self-care, problem-solving).
phenotypic_evidence.comorbidities: Hyperventilation with apnea; Tremulousness; Hypertonicity (legs); Abnormal EEG with bilateral central spikes

variant.sequencing_method_details: PCR amplification and fragment/sequence analysis of MECP2 exon 4; shorter deleted allele preferentially amplified
variant.variant: Exon 4 quintuple deletion: 1042del14; 1060del14; 1100del3; 1137del26; 1177del8 (total −65 bp); frameshift after K347; premature stop at p.*381
variant.variant_description: Five adjacent intragenic deletions within exon 4 detected by sequencing and fragment analysis; shorter deleted allele preferentially amplified.
variant.impact: Frameshift leading to truncated protein (486 aa → 381 aa).
variant.segregation_data: PCR showed both normal and deleted alleles; parents unavailable for testing.

cases.description: A 6-year-old Taiwanese female, product of IVF, with early development including two words by age 1 and walking at 15 months. Later showed autistic behavior, impaired balance, hypertonicity, breathing difficulties including hyperventilation, and abnormal EEG consistent with a seizure disorder. At age 6 she exhibited typical autistic behavior, hand-wringing movements, developmental delay, dystonia, suspected atonic seizures at night, bruxism, hyperventilation, and head circumference at the 2nd percentile. Genetic testing identified a triple deletion in MECP2 exon 4 totaling −113 bp, causing a frameshift and premature termination (364 aa protein).
cases.family_history: Mother had breast cancer; conceived by IVF; high-resolution karyotypes of proband and parents normal.
cases.notes: PCR showed predominant amplification of the shorter deleted allele with minor normal-length product; both parents tested normal at the Rett locus, consistent with a de novo event.
quotes: Only limited information exists on this 6-year-old Taiwanese female...
When examined, her autistic behavior was noted, as was the lack of progress in language acquisition.
When seen again at the age of 6, she exhibited typical autistic behavior, hand-wringing movements, and was considerably delayed.
She was dystonic and thought to have atonic seizures at night, grinding of her teeth, and hyperventilating. Her head circumference was in the 2nd percentile.

The MECP 2 exon 4 gene regions of propositus 2 were again sequenced... The first unequal recombination site deleting 15 bp... the second... 28 bp... the third... 70 bp... Together, these three deletions result in an exon 4 that is 113 bp shorter...
Thus, the gene terminates 19 amino acids after the first deletion, resulting in a 364-amino acid translated protein instead of the normal 486-amino acid protein (Fig. 4B3).
a small quantity of normal length PCR amplified product could be observed in the same electrophoretic lane as the amplified abnormal allele (sample C1 in Fig. 2B).
Subsequently, testing available DNAs confirmed that two different X chromosomes are present in approximately equal quantities in each propositus (Table 4).
Rett: DeletionX3 ... Father of propositus 2: Normal ... Mother of propositus 2: Normal

phenotypic_evidence.comorbidities: Impaired balance; Hypertonicity; Breathing difficulties including hyperventilation; Abnormal EEG consistent with seizure disorder; Dystonia; Suspected atonic seizures at night; Bruxism; Microcephaly (HC 2nd percentile)

variant.impact: Frameshift leading to truncated protein (486 aa → 364 aa).
variant.segregation_data: Table 4 indicates proband carries DeletionX3 while both father and mother are normal; two different X chromosomes present in proband.

title: Role of a conserved glutamine in the function of voltage-gated Ca 2 ÷ channels revealed by a mutation in human CACNA1D
author: Garza-Lopez E, et al.

cases.description: The male proband was the first-born child of healthy parents who were first cousins of Arabic descent. The father had a history of febrile seizures since childhood. The proband was born after an uneventful pregnancy and delivered at 38 weeks of gestation by cesarean section because of fetal distress. He failed the hearing test at birth and had seizures beginning at 4 months of age. At the age of 4 1 /2 years, he was reassessed at the genetic clinic for the purpose of family planning. He did not speak and his comprehension was limited. He exhibited autistic behaviors including very limited eye contact and hyperactivity. He wore hearing aids from the age of 11 months. At 5 years of age, he underwent hearing tests which revealed moderate hearing loss (40-50 db SPL across all frequencies from 500 Hz to 40 kHz). Whole-exome sequencing and filtering for homozygous variants revealed two potential candidate genes: A homozygous mutation in the otogelin gene (OTOG) ... and a homozygous missense variant in CACNA1D: Chr3 (GRCh37): g.53756476G > C; NM_000720.3: c.1701G > C (p.Gln567His). ... Both parents were heterozygous for the OTOG and CACNA1D variants. The high degree of consanguinity within the family was the basis for assuming a recessive model of inheritance. ... CACNA1D variants have also been associated with autism spectrum disorders (8) and epilepsy (8, 17, 18). Because of the coincident involvement of CACNA1D in the proband's symptoms (i.e. hearing loss, epilepsy, autism), we analyzed the functional consequences of the CACNA1D in a heterologous expression system.
cases.family_history: father had a history of febrile seizures since childhood; parents are first cousins
cases.notes: Also carries a homozygous OTOG c.4439C>T (p.Thr1480Ile) variant, likely relevant to hearing loss. Homozygous for CACNA1D variant due to consanguinity.
quotes: He failed the hearing test at birth and had seizures beginning at 4 months of age. At the age of 4 1/2 years, he was reassessed at the genetic clinic for the purpose of family planning. He did not speak and his comprehension was limited. He exhibited autistic behaviors including very limited eye contact and hyperactivity.

Whole-exome sequencing and filtering for homozygous variants revealed two potential candidate genes: ... a homozygous missense variant in CACNA1D: Chr3 (GRCh37): g.53756476G > C; NM_000720.3: c.1701G > C (p.Gln567His).
Both parents were heterozygous for the OTOG and CACNA1D variants.

CACNA1D variants have also been associated with autism spectrum disorders (8) and epilepsy (8, 17, 18). Because of the coincident involvement of CACNA1D in the proband's symptoms (i.e. hearing loss, epilepsy, autism), we analyzed the functional consequences of the CACNA1D in a heterologous expression system.

phenotypic_evidence.cognitive_ability_cautionary_comment: No formal cognitive assessment scores provided but clear evidence of ID.

phenotypic_evidence.comorbidities: hearing impairment, epilepsy, intellectual disability
phenotypic_evidence.phenotypes: epilepsy, hearing loss, developmental delay

variant.sequencing_method_details: trio sequencing, filtered for homozygous variants in consanguineous family
variant.region: extracellular S1-S2 loop of domain II
variant.variant_description: Homozygous missense variant in CACNA1D in male with epilepsy, moderate hearing loss, ID, ASD. The glutamine residue is highly conserved.
variant.impact: Significant reduction in Cav1.3 current density and suppressed voltage-dependent inactivation; likely impairment in trafficking of Cav1.3 to the cell surface.
variant.segregation_data: Both parents heterozygous for OTOG and CACNA1D variants; consanguinity in family.

title: Genome sequencing detects a balanced pericentric inversion with breakpoints that impact the DMD and upstream region of POU3F4 genes
author: Chandrasekhar A, et al.

cases.description: We present a 10-year-old male with muscular dystrophy, autism spectrum disorder, diastolic dysfunction, developmental delay, seizures, and sensorineural hearing loss. Clinical whole-genome sequencing revealed a novel hemizygous 50.7 Mb balanced pericentric inversion on chromosome X with breakpoints in intron 55 of DMD and 443 kb upstream of POU3F4; the inversion was detected in the proband, his affected maternal half-brother, and their mother (heterozygous carrier).
cases.family_history: Maternal half-brother affected with similar features; mother is heterozygous carrier for the inversion and has seizures but is otherwise unaffected.
cases.notes: Balanced pericentric inversion impacts DMD (intronic breakpoint) and upstream regulatory region of POU3F4. Karyotype confirmation successful in mother and affected brother; proband's cell culture failed for karyotype, but inversion detected by cWGS and visually confirmed by analysts.
quotes: Abstract: "We describe a family with two maternal half-brothers both of whom presented with muscular dystrophy, autism spectrum disorder, developmental delay, and sensorineural hearing loss."
Case Report: "We present a 10-year-old male with muscular dystrophy, autism spectrum disorder, diastolic dysfunction, developmental delay, seizures, and sensorineural hearing loss."

Results/Genetics: "cWGS ... revealed a novel hemizygous 50.7 Mb balanced pericentric inversion on chromosome X that disrupts the DMD gene in both siblings... This inversion also impacts the upstream regulatory region of POU3F4... The unaffected mother is a heterozygous carrier for the pericentric inversion."

Results/Genetics: "corresponding to a 50.7 Mb balanced pericentric inversion, grch37: X:31626542-82320140. The first breakpoint occurs on Xp21.1 (grch37:X:31626542), in intron 55 (NM_004006) of the DMD gene... The second breakpoint occurs on Xq21.1 (grch37:X:82320140), which is 443 kb upstream of the POU3F4 gene."
Results/Genetics: "The balanced pericentric inversion was detected in the proband, affected maternal half-brother, and mother (heterozygous carrier for the inversion)."
Figure 1 legend: "The breakpoint on Xp21.1 ... occurs at intron 55 ... predicted to result in premature transcription termination and non-sense mediated decay."

phenotypic_evidence.developmental_milestones: Developmental and motor delay noted at 11 months.
phenotypic_evidence.comorbidities: Duchenne muscular dystrophy/dystrophinopathy; diastolic dysfunction; developmental delay; seizures; sensorineural hearing loss; elevated creatine kinase

variant.sequencing_method: Clinical whole-genome sequencing (cWGS); high-resolution karyotyping in mother and affected brother; inversion visually confirmed by analysts
variant.region: Xp21.1 (DMD intron 55) and Xq21.1 (~443 kb upstream of POU3F4)
variant.variant_description: Novel 50.7 Mb balanced pericentric inversion on chromosome X disrupting DMD and impacting upstream regulatory region of POU3F4.
variant.impact: Breakpoint in DMD intron 55 predicted to cause premature transcription termination and nonsense-mediated decay; breakpoint upstream of POU3F4 associated with hearing loss.
variant.segregation_data: Detected in proband and affected maternal half-brother; mother heterozygous carrier. Karyotype 46,Y,inv(X)(p21.1q21.1) confirmed in mother and affected brother; proband sample failed cell culture for karyotype but inversion detected by cWGS and visually confirmed by analysts.

cases.score_rationale: Variant: predicted_null (maternal) | Initial score: 1.5 (range: 0-2.0) | Phenotype adjustment (low confidence): -0.5 | Final quantized score: 1.0

cases.description: Maternal half-brother, 4 years younger than the proband, presented with similar features of muscular dystrophy, autism, developmental delay, sensorineural hearing loss, and elevated creatine kinase. cWGS detected the same hemizygous 50.7 Mb balanced pericentric inversion on chromosome X with breakpoints in DMD intron 55 and ~443 kb upstream of POU3F4; karyotyping confirmed the inversion in this affected brother.
cases.family_history: Proband similarly affected; mother is heterozygous carrier for the inversion and has seizures.
cases.notes: Karyotype confirmation successful in affected brother. ASD explicitly stated among clinical features.
quotes: Abstract: "We describe a family with two maternal half-brothers both of whom presented with muscular dystrophy, autism spectrum disorder, developmental delay, and sensorineural hearing loss."

Case Report: "The family history was notable for an affected maternal half-brother, 4 years younger than the proband who presented with similar features of muscular dystrophy, autism, developmental delay, sensorineural hearing loss, and elevated creatine kinase."
Results/Genetics: "The balanced pericentric inversion was detected in the proband, affected maternal half-brother, and mother (heterozygous carrier for the inversion)."
Figure 2 legend: "Highresolution karyotyping confirming the pericentric inversion in the mother (left chromosome) and the affected brother (arrows depict the breakpoints)."

phenotypic_evidence.comorbidities: Duchenne muscular dystrophy/dystrophinopathy; developmental delay; sensorineural hearing loss; elevated creatine kinase

variant.sequencing_method: Clinical whole-genome sequencing (cWGS); high-resolution karyotyping confirmed inversion in this brother and mother
variant.region: Xp21.1 (DMD intron 55) and Xq21.1 (~443 kb upstream of POU3F4)
variant.variant_description: Novel 50.7 Mb balanced pericentric inversion on chromosome X disrupting DMD and impacting upstream regulatory region of POU3F4.
variant.impact: Breakpoint in DMD intron 55 predicted to cause premature transcription termination and nonsense-mediated decay; breakpoint upstream of POU3F4 associated with hearing loss.
variant.segregation_data: Detected in affected maternal half-brother and proband; mother heterozygous carrier. Karyotype 46,Y,inv(X)(p21.1q21.1) confirmed in mother and affected brother.

cases.description: A749T in a female referred at 3 years; diagnosed with ASD, global developmental delay, muscle hypotonia; severe self-injurious behaviors; trialed multiple medications.

quotes: A749T
1 year (f)

The female patient was referred to a local autism center at 3 years of age. Her medical history revealed diagnoses of ASD, global developmental delay, muscle hypotonia, delayed vision maturation, and difficulty walking.

the family was seeking medication management for impulsive and unpredictable self-harming events which occurred multiple times a day including biting herself, scratching to the point of bleeding, throwing herself to the ground, hitting her head against hard surfaces, punching a car so hard it ' bloodied her knuckles, ' and other significant self-injurious events.
a whole exome sequence was completed 2 years later revealing the CACNA1D variant.
A short trial with immediate release isradipine was initiated ... but was stopped because of concern for worsened symptoms, inefficacy, and complication by a common cold
Binocular vision disorder

title: Identification of a Family With Nonspecific Mental Retardation (MRX79) With the A140V Mutation in the MECP2 Gene: Is There a Need for Routine Screening?
author: Winnepenninckx B, et al.

cases.description: In family MRX79, Patient III-6 had severe mental retardation with "some autistic features" and carried the MECP2 A140V substitution identified in all patients with the disease haplotype.
cases.family_history: Three-generation family with five affected males; X-linked segregation with disease haplotype.
cases.notes: ASD-related features noted without formal ASD diagnosis or standardized assessments.
quotes: Patient III-6 is enrolled in a special educational system for mentally retarded children. Apart from severe mental retardation, he shows facial dysmorphism, some autistic features, obesity, gynecomastia, and hypogonadism, a clinical picture reminiscent of Borjeson-
In exon 3 of the MECP2 gene we identified a missense C -T transition in position 419, resulting in a substitution of alanine to valine at codon 140 (reviewed but not shown).
The substitution was identified in all patients with the disease haplotype, but not in patient III-7 who has a different haplotype.
All carrier females were heterozygous for the substitution.

phenotypic_evidence.core_asd_symptoms: some autistic features
phenotypic_evidence.cognitive_ability_cautionary_comment: Severe intellectual disability is present; without A or B indicators for ASD, phenotype confidence is reduced.
phenotypic_evidence.developmental_milestones: Severe mental retardation; enrolled in a special educational system.
phenotypic_evidence.comorbidities: Facial dysmorphism; obesity; gynecomastia; hypogonadism.

variant.variant_description: Missense variant in methyl-binding domain; reported as recurrent in X-linked mental retardation and not found in 100 control males in this study.
variant.segregation_data: Identified in all patients with the disease haplotype; absent in III-7; carrier females heterozygous.

title: Preserved speech variant is allelic of classic Rett syndrome
author: De Bona C, et al.

cases.description: Case32 (Figure 1) has a healthy younger sister. Family history does not show the presence of a neurological disorder in three generations. After a normal pregnancy and delivery, her initial development was delayed. She was able to walk alone at 15 months, and speak her first words at the same age. At 18 months motor deterioration began with uncertain gait, hypotonus, and tremor in the hands accompanied by loss of their functional use. At the same time she lost the few words which she could speak, as well as her ability to relate. Some months later, stereotypic hand clapping and hand-washing activities appeared. In the following years, she recovered some degree of visual interaction with people and from 5years of age she slowly began to recover some functional use of her hands, in which intention tremor and stereotypic activities remained present until 9 years of age when she was admitted to the Department of Child Neuropsychiatry of Siena. ... She had an ataxic gait and could say a few words in an echolalic manner. ... In the following years, her speech became more complex with the appearance of short phrases, pronounced in the second and third person, and echolalic. From age 10 there was a slow motor deterioration and now at 22years she is in a wheel chair, maintains her stereotypic hand activities and can still say a few words, although less than at the beginning of adolescence.
cases.cohort_name: preserved speech variant (PSV) of the Rett complex
cases.family_history: Healthy younger sister; no neurological disorder reported in three generations.
cases.notes: Paper states that two PSV cases (case 32 and case 109) carry small frameshift deletions in MECP2 (one 41 bp and one 44 bp) causing truncation at p.404, but does not specify which exact deletion (1157del41 vs 1159del44) corresponds to case 32.
quotes: “Case32 (Figure 1) has a healthy younger sister. Family history does not show the presence of a neurological disorder in three generations.” (Materials and methods – Variants, case descriptions)
“Some months later, stereotypic hand clapping and hand-washing activities appeared.” (Materials and methods – Variants, case descriptions)
“She had an ataxic gait and could say a few words in an echolalic manner.” (Materials and methods – Variants, case descriptions)

“In the following years, her speech became more complex with the appearance of short phrases, pronounced in the second and third person, and echolalic.” (Materials and methods – Variants, case descriptions)
“Four very similar small deletions were found in two classic RTT patients and in two (out of three) preserved speech variants (case 32 and case 109, Figure 3).” (Results)

“The deletion of 41 bp (starting from nt1157) and the two deletions of 41bp and 44bp (starting from nt1159) led to the same frameshift and to protein truncation in position 404, after a short stretch of incorrect amino acids.” (Results)
“1157del41 … Phenotype: PSV” and “1159del44 … Phenotype: PSV” (Table 1)
“Their behaviour fulfils the characteristics of an autistic disorder.” (Discussion – referring to PSV)

phenotypic_evidence.core_asd_symptoms: Stereotypic hand activities; loss of social relatedness; echolalia; PSV explicitly linked to autistic disorder in discussion.
phenotypic_evidence.cognitive_ability_cautionary_comment: Insufficient information to classify intellectual ability; no standardized IQ or adaptive scores reported.
phenotypic_evidence.developmental_milestones: Walked and spoke first words at 15 months; regression at 18 months with motor deterioration and loss of words; later partial recovery of speech (short echolalic phrases) and hand use.
phenotypic_evidence.comorbidities: Ataxic gait; kyphoscoliosis; overweight; large head within 2 SD; no epileptic seizures reported.
phenotypic_evidence.phenotypes: Rett preserved speech variant (PSV); uncertain gait; hypotonus; hand tremor; stereotypic hand clapping/hand-washing; echolalic speech; progressive motor deterioration leading to wheelchair use.

variant.region: 3′ coding region (downstream of the transcription repression domain)
variant.variant: c.1157del41 or c.1159del44 (exact assignment to this case not specified); frameshift with truncation at ~p.(…/404*)
variant.variant_description: Small out-of-frame deletion (41 bp or 44 bp) near nt1157/1159 in MECP2; creates frameshift and truncation at position 404.
variant.impact: Frameshift resulting in premature truncation at amino acid position 404.

cases.score_rationale: Variant: predicted_null (unknown) | Initial score: 1.5 (range: 0-2.0) | Phenotype adjustment (medium confidence): -0.25 | Genotypic downgrades: Sequencing method not provided: -0.5 | Final quantized score: 0.75

cases.description: Case109 has already been fully described as case report (case I-12) in Zappella et al . At present the patient is 13 years old, is in the third stage and her conditions have remained essentially the same as in the description given. She is an obese girl with a high kyphosis, has continuous stereotypic hand-washing activities, speaks in short phrases in the second and third person with echolalias, and has a mental age close to 3-4 years. She also has flat feet, genu valgum and a dyspraxic gait. She has a large head circumference (56.5 cm), albeit within 2 SD. A recent waking EEG shows a basic rhythm of 8 c/s with bursts of 6-7 c/s activities: she has never had epileptic seizures.

quotes: “Case109 has already been fully described as case report (case I-12) in Zappella et al . … At present the patient is 13 years old … She is an obese girl with a high kyphosis, has continuous stereotypic hand-washing activities, speaks in short phrases in the second and third person with echolalias … She has a large head circumference (56.5 cm) … she has never had epileptic seizures.” (Materials and methods – Variants, case descriptions)
“Four very similar small deletions were found in two classic RTT patients and in two (out of three) preserved speech variants (case 32 and case 109, Figure 3).” (Results)

“The deletion of 41 bp (starting from nt1157) and the two deletions of 41bp and 44bp (starting from nt1159) led to the same frameshift and to protein truncation in position 404, after a short stretch of incorrect amino acids.” (Results)
“1157del41 … Phenotype: PSV” and “1159del44 … Phenotype: PSV” (Table 1)
“Their behaviour fulfils the characteristics of an autistic disorder.” (Discussion – referring to PSV)

title: The Clinical and Genetic Features of Co-occurring Epilepsy and Autism Spectrum Disorder in Chinese Children
author: Long S, et al.

quotes: ASD was assessed with the Autism Behavior Checklist, completed by parents, for patients at least 18-month-old with core symptoms of ASD. When the score on the questionnaire was > 61, ASD was considered. Then, all ASD patients were diagnosed by qualified and experienced neurologists and psychologists using the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of 5. Mental Disorders V (DSM-V) published in 2013 and based on the patient's clinical behavior.
Clinical judgment was based on all available questionnaires including the ADOS (Autism diagnostic observation schedule) and the ADI-R (Autism diagnostic interview-revised).
All children aged 1-18 years diagnosed with epilepsy with ASDfrom January 1st, 2015, to May 1st, 2018

title: MECP2 analysis in mentally retarded patients: implications for routine DNA diagnostics
author: Kleefstra T, et al.

cases.description: In the Fragile-X-negative panel, one nonsense mutation c.1216C -T (p.Q406X). The mutation was not found in the parents. X-inactivation studies in the patient lymphocytes showed a 100% skewed pattern. This girl was born at the term after an uneventful pregnancy and delivery with a birth weight of 2550g. Psychomotor development was delayed; she walked at 3 years and spoke her first words at the age of 5 years. At the age of 16 years, she attended an institute for child psychiatry because of behavioral problems. She was moderately retarded, had EEG abnormalities, behavioural problems and autistic features without spasticity.
cases.family_history: Mutation not found in parents; X-inactivation 100% skewed in lymphocytes
cases.notes: Clinical section titled 'p.Q406X'. Examined at age 22 years; moderate intellectual disability. X-inactivation pattern completely skewed; allele-specific inactivation unknown. Source: Main text: Results/DNA studies; Clinical studies of patients with a MECP2 mutation p.Q406X; Discussion
quotes: Results/DNA studies: "In the Fragile-X-negative panel, two sequence changes were found, one known polymorphism c.1126C -T (p.P376S) and one nonsense mutation c.1216C -T (p.Q406X). The mutation was not found in the parents. X-inactivation studies in the patient lymphocytes showed a 100% skewed pattern."
Clinical studies p.Q406X: "Psychomotor development was delayed; she walked at 3 years and spoke her first words at the age of 5 years."
Clinical studies p.Q406X: "At the age of 16 years, she attended an institute for child psychiatry because of behavioral problems. The degree of mental retardation was moderate."
Discussion (referring to this patient): "She was moderately retarded, had EEG abnormalities, behavioural problems and autistic features without spasticity."

phenotypic_evidence.core_asd_symptoms: Autistic features; behavioral problems; delayed speech
phenotypic_evidence.developmental_milestones: Walked at 3 years; first words at 5 years
phenotypic_evidence.comorbidities: EEG abnormalities; unsteady gait; strabismus; behavioral problems
phenotypic_evidence.phenotypes: Child-like facial appearance; slightly unsteady gait; height 160 cm (~−1.5 SD); head circumference 56 cm (~+0.5 SD) at age 22

variant.variant_description: Truncating variant in C-terminal region; de novo; skewed X-inactivation
variant.segregation_data: Not detected in either parent; skewed X-inactivation (100%)

cases.description: In the Angelman-negative group, two known pathogenic missense mutations were found: c.397C -T (p.R133C) in a female patient ... The p.R133C was not found in the mother. After 6 months of normal development, there was developmental stagnation, and only a slow further progression. She walked at 24 months and spoke her first words at 5 years of age. Though our patient did meet several criteria for classical RTT syndrome, there was no history of regression; she did not have the acquired microcephaly and stereotypic handmovements.
cases.family_history: Mother negative for the variant; father not reported
cases.notes: Clinical section titled 'p.R133C'. Atypical Rett features (no regression, no stereotypic hand movements). Severe intellectual disability. Source: Main text: Results/DNA studies; Clinical studies of patients with a MECP2 mutation p.R133C; Discussion
quotes: Results/DNA studies: "In the Angelman-negative group, two known pathogenic missense mutations were found: c.397C -T (p.R133C) in a female patient and a mosaic c.473G -T (p.T158M) in a male patient... The p.R133C was not found in the mother."

Clinical studies p.R133C: "After 6 months of normal development, there was developmental stagnation, and only a slow further progression. ... She walked at 24 months and spoke her first words at 5 years of age."

Clinical studies p.R133C: "On investigation at the age of 7 years, she had normal height and head circumference, and was slightly obese. She was a severely retarded, friendly and happy person, and spoke with two-words sentences."

Clinical studies p.R133C: "Since the age of 7 years, there were severe sleep disturbances. Daytime EEG studies showed epileptic activity in less than 1%, whereas during the night more than 75% disturbed EEG patterns were observed. In spite of EEG abnormalities, no convulsions had been observed."
Clinical studies p.R133C (age 14): "She was a friendly person with growth retardation ... generalised obesity ... and hypotonia. ... Her gait was unsteady and wide-based."
Discussion: "Though our patient did meet several criteria for classical RTT syndrome, there was no history of regression; she did not have the acquired microcephaly and stereotypic handmovements."

phenotypic_evidence.core_asd_symptoms: Rett-like features (met several criteria), severe intellectual disability, limited speech
phenotypic_evidence.developmental_milestones: Walked at 24 months; first words at 5 years
phenotypic_evidence.comorbidities: Sleep disturbances; EEG abnormalities; hypotonia; obesity; scoliosis (thoracic)
phenotypic_evidence.phenotypes: Insensitive to pain; wide-based gait; tapering fingers; cold extremities

variant.variant_description: Recurrent Rett-associated missense in methyl-binding domain; mother negative
variant.segregation_data: Mother negative; paternal status not stated

cases.score_rationale: Variant: missense (unknown) | Initial score: 0.5 (range: 0-1) | Genotypic downgrades: Sequencing method not provided: -0.35 | Final quantized score: 0.15

cases.description: In the Angelman-negative group, a mosaic c.473G -T (p.T158M) in a male patient. The mother of the male patient with the mosaic p.T158M mutation did not have this mutation. At the age of 2 years and 9 months, he was a passive boy with autistic features and hardly any speech. Stereotypic movements like handclapping and teeth grounding were noted. There were convulsions and diffuse EEG abnormalities. He shows the classical Rett syndrome phenotype.
cases.family_history: Mother negative for the variant; mosaicism (~25% mutant allele in lymphocytes)
cases.notes: Clinical section titled 'p.T158M'. Mosaic mutation; wheelchair-bound at 11 years; severe scoliosis. Source: Main text: Results/DNA studies; Clinical studies of patients with a MECP2 mutation p.T158M; Figure 2 legend; Discussion
quotes: Results/DNA studies: "In the Angelman-negative group, two known pathogenic missense mutations were found: ... a mosaic c.473G -T (p.T158M) in a male patient... The mother of the male patient with the mosaic p.T158M mutation did not have this mutation."

Clinical studies p.T158M: "At the age of 2 years and 9 months, he was a passive boy with autistic features and hardly any speech. Stereotypic movements like handclapping and teeth grounding were noted. There were convulsions and diffuse EEG abnormalities."
Figure 2 legend: "Male patient with the p.T158M mosaic mutation in MECP2 at the age of 11 years. He shows the classical Rett syndrome phenotype."
Discussion: "The percentage of mutant versus wild-type allele was estimated to be 25%."

phenotypic_evidence.core_asd_symptoms: Autistic features; stereotypic hand movements; severe language impairment
phenotypic_evidence.developmental_milestones: Initial normal development in first year; later stagnation and regression
phenotypic_evidence.comorbidities: Convulsions; diffuse EEG abnormalities; sleep disturbances; severe thoracic scoliosis; wheelchair-bound
phenotypic_evidence.phenotypes: Yelling/shouting episodes; small cold feet; loss of purposeful hand use; regression of motor abilities

variant.variant_description: Mosaic recurrent Rett-associated missense in methyl-binding domain; mother negative; estimated 25% mutant allele in lymphocytes
variant.segregation_data: Mother negative; mosaic in proband (~25% mutant allele in lymphocytes)

title: Rett Syndrome: Long-Term Clinical Follow-Up Experiences Over Four Decades
author: Hagberg B

cases.description: She has a complex MECP2 rearrangement with deletions both of exon 3 and exon 4, as reported in detail by Erlandsson and Hagberg in this issue. To summarize, this 47-year-old woman fulfills the criteria for classic Rett syndrome stage III.
cases.family_history: Born in 1957 to a healthy family
cases.notes: Classic Rett syndrome stage III at latest follow-up; long-term ambulatory ability preserved but with dystonic foot postures and motor dyspraxia.
quotes: Case S-1, born in 1957 to a healthy family, was referred at age 3.5 years from central Sweden to the author because of unexplained developmental deviations and some sort of seizure-like episodes starting 6 months earlier. (Case S-1)
She had subsequently and completely stopped grasping and no longer used her hands at all and had started performing peculiar hand-wringing stereotypies. (Case S-1)
In 2004, at the latest follow-up, at the age of 47 years, she was a very small woman, 134 cm tall, weighing 50 kg, with an OFC of 54 cm. (Case S-1)
She has a complex MECP2 rearrangement with deletions both of exon 3 and exon 4, as reported in detail by Erlandsson and Hagberg in this issue. (Case S-1)
To summarize, this 47-year-old woman fulfills the criteria for classic Rett syndrome stage III. (Case S-1)

phenotypic_evidence.age_at_diagnosis: 3.5 years (referred for developmental deviations; Rett diagnosis noted later)
phenotypic_evidence.core_asd_symptoms: Developmental regression with loss of purposeful hand use; stereotypic hand-wringing; impaired social interaction/communication consistent with Rett.
phenotypic_evidence.diagnostic_criteria_used: Rett syndrome diagnostic criteria (classic, stage III)
phenotypic_evidence.cognitive_ability_cautionary_comment: No formal ASD diagnostic tools reported; Rett diagnosis with clear social-communication impairment and stereotypies supports ASD features.
phenotypic_evidence.developmental_milestones: Normal development during first ~1.5 years; subsequently stopped grasping/hand use and regressed in psychomotor development.
phenotypic_evidence.comorbidities: History of epileptiform symptoms (controlled by late adolescence); growth retardation; kyphosis; scoliosis; dystonic foot malpositions; low nociception.
phenotypic_evidence.phenotypes: Small stature; motor dyspraxia; stereotypic hand movements; scoliosis/kyphosis; dystonia; low pain sensitivity.

variant.variant_description: Complex deletion affecting MECP2 exons 3 and 4; detailed characterization referenced to Erlandsson and Hagberg.

cases.description: She has a commonly found MECP2 mutation in exon 4 (R270X). To summarize, this woman fulfills all of the criteria for classic Rett syndrome stage IVB and exhibits a large majority of the supportive criteria.
cases.family_history: Second of three siblings in a healthy family
cases.notes: Classic Rett syndrome stage IVB; severe dystonic-rigid syndrome with marked kyphoscoliosis; no history of epileptic seizures.
quotes: Case S-2, born in 1960, is the second of three siblings in a healthy family. (Case S-2)

At the age of 1.75 years, she had stopped walking completely, had lost contact with her parents, had developed intense 'hand-clapping' stereotypies (movie documented), and showed autistic traits. (Case S-2)
In 2004, at age 44 years (Figure 2), she was an extreme invalid, very small and thin, with a small head (height 130 cm, weight 24 kg, OFC 48.5 cm). (Case S-2)
She has a commonly found MECP2 mutation in exon 4 (R270X). (Case S-2)
To summarize, this woman fulfills all of the criteria for classic Rett syndrome stage IVB and exhibits a large majority of the supportive criteria. (Case S-2)
She has never had any epileptic seizures. (Case S-2)

phenotypic_evidence.core_asd_symptoms: Autistic traits with loss of social contact; developmental regression; intense stereotypic hand movements (hand-clapping).
phenotypic_evidence.diagnostic_criteria_used: Rett syndrome diagnostic criteria (classic, stage IVB)
phenotypic_evidence.cognitive_ability_cautionary_comment: No formal ASD diagnostic tools reported; Rett diagnosis with clear social-communication deficits and stereotypies supports ASD features.
phenotypic_evidence.developmental_milestones: Normal first ~1.25 years with walking support and pincer grasp; subsequent regression including loss of walking and language; head growth deceleration.
phenotypic_evidence.comorbidities: Severe dystonic-rigid syndrome; marked kyphoscoliosis; distended abdomen; cold, small, dystrophic feet; microcephaly; no epileptic seizures.
phenotypic_evidence.phenotypes: Microcephaly; severe motor impairment; kyphoscoliosis; dystrophic feet; failure to thrive/low weight.

variant.variant_description: Nonsense variant R270X in MECP2 exon 4; described as commonly found in Rett syndrome.

title: Identification of MeCP2 Mutations in a Series of Females with Autistic Disorder
author: Carney RM, et al.

cases.description: 16-year-old female with AutD confirmed by ADI-R/DSM-IV. Heterozygous 41-bp deletion in MECP2 (1157del41) causing a truncating frameshift; reported as de novo. VABS showed functioning equivalent to 60 months.
cases.cohort_name: 69 females clinically diagnosed with autistic disorder screened for MECP2 mutations
cases.family_history: No family history of mental retardation, RTT, or AutD.
cases.notes: X-chromosome inactivation in blood showed borderline skewing (31%). Father unavailable for sequencing in main text; figure caption indicates de novo based on family member testing.
quotes: “Patient 1 is a 16-year-old female.” [Results – Patient 1: Developmental History]
“The patient met DSM-IV diagnostic criteria for AutD as confirmed by the ADI-R.” [Results – Patient 1: Clinical Evaluation]
“Administration of the VABS indicated a current level of functioning equivalent to 60 months.” [Results – Patient 1: Clinical Evaluation]

“Sequencing of the patient's MeCP2 gene demonstrated a heterozygous 41-bp deletion at nucleotides 1157-1197 (numbered from the start of the coding region; Fig 1).” [Results – Patient 1: MeCP2 Analysis]
“This 1157del41 mutation causes a frameshift resulting in a MeCP2 protein truncated to 389 amino acids from the normal 486.” [Results – Patient 1: MeCP2 Analysis]
“The family members of Patient 1 demonstrated no change on sequencing, indicating that this is a de novo mutation.” [Figure 1 caption]

“The sequence of the MeCP2 gene in the patient's two sisters, mother, and paternal grandparents was normal (data not shown). The father was unavailable for analysis.” [Results – Patient 1: MeCP2 Analysis]
“There is no family history of mental retardation, RTT, or AutD.” [Results – Patient 1: Developmental History]
“All 69 AutD-diagnosed females were screened for mutations in the MeCP2 gene.” [Materials and Methods – Family studies and patient evaluation]

phenotypic_evidence.core_asd_symptoms: AutD diagnosis via ADI-R; language delay/regression; social communication impairment.
phenotypic_evidence.cognitive_ability_cautionary_comment: Severe ID indicated by low adaptive functioning, but ASD diagnosis supported by ADI-R and DSM-IV.
phenotypic_evidence.developmental_milestones: Normal until 18 months; first words and phrases achieved on time; later language development stopped progressing.
phenotypic_evidence.comorbidities: Dystonic posturing of left arm when walking; occasional side-to-side stereotypic head movements.
phenotypic_evidence.phenotypes: Head circumference at 50th percentile; normal at birth; no stereotypic hand movements (wringing/clapping) observed; no truncal ataxia; gait normal-based; no scoliosis.

variant.sequencing_method_details: Sequencing of MECP2 coding region; family members tested (sisters, mother, paternal grandparents) were negative; father unavailable.
variant.variant_description: Heterozygous 41-bp deletion (1157del41) causing frameshift; truncates MeCP2 to 389 aa; previously reported in classic RTT.
variant.segregation_data: Sisters, mother, and paternal grandparents negative; father unavailable; figure caption states family members showed no change indicating de novo.

cases.score_rationale: Variant: predicted_null (de_novo) | Initial score: 2.0 (range: 0-2.5) | Genotypic downgrades: Very small/exclusive gene panel - score set to 0 | Final quantized score: 0.0

cases.description: 10-year-old female with AutD confirmed by ADI-R/DSM-IV. Heterozygous nonsense variant c.880C>T (R294X) in MECP2; de novo. VABS functioning equivalent to 32 months; EEG abnormalities; seizures noted in supportive criteria.
cases.cohort_name: 69 females clinically diagnosed with autistic disorder screened for MECP2 mutations
cases.notes: X-chromosome inactivation in blood showed borderline skewing (29%).
quotes: “Patient two is a 10-year-old female…” [Results – Patient 2: Developmental History]
“The patient met DSM-IV diagnostic criteria for AutD as confirmed by the ADI-R [28].” [Results – Patient 2: Clinical Evaluation]
“Administration of the VABS [27] reveals that she functions at a level equivalent to 32 months of age.” [Results – Patient 2: Clinical Evaluation]
“Sequencing indicates that this patient has a single nucleotide sequence change 880 C 3 T (Fig 2).” [Results – Patient 2: MeCP2 Analysis]
“This nonsense mutation (R294X) is one of the most frequent mutations found in RTT…” [Results – Patient 2: MeCP2 Analysis]
“The father, mother, and brother were not found to carry the change, confirming that this is a de novo mutation (data not shown).” [Results – Patient 2: MeCP2 Analysis]
“Sequence exhibits a heterozygous C 3 T change at nucleotide 880, which translates into a R294X nonsense mutation.” [Figure 2 caption]
“An intermittent, nonspecific electroencephalogram (EEG) abnormality was noted in the patient.” [Results – Patient 2: Developmental History]
“Seizures +” [Table 1 – Supportive criteria]
“All 69 AutD-diagnosed females were screened for mutations in the MeCP2 gene.” [Materials and Methods – Family studies and patient evaluation]

phenotypic_evidence.core_asd_symptoms: AutD diagnosis via ADI-R; language loss/regression; social communication impairment.
phenotypic_evidence.cognitive_ability_cautionary_comment: Severe ID indicated by low adaptive functioning, but ASD diagnosis supported by ADI-R and DSM-IV.
phenotypic_evidence.developmental_milestones: First single words at 12 months, two-word phrases at 24 months; regression at 30 months with loss of language, motor skills, and adaptive behavior.
phenotypic_evidence.comorbidities: Intermittent, nonspecific EEG abnormality; seizures.
phenotypic_evidence.phenotypes: Left esotropia; diminished grip strength; wide-based gait at exam (previously able to tandem gait at 5 years); some use of neologisms and verbal rituals; no stereotypic hand movements (wringing/clapping/clenching) observed.

variant.sequencing_method_details: Sequencing of MECP2 coding region; trio testing showed parents and brother negative, confirming de novo.
variant.variant_description: Heterozygous nonsense mutation R294X; one of the most frequent mutations in RTT; confirmed de novo.
variant.segregation_data: Father, mother, and brother do not carry the change; confirmed de novo.

cases.description: Narrative case description provided: "The patient with the large deletion (c.868_1188del321) was a girl, she was the firstborn child to a nonconsanguineous couple... She was heterozygous for c.868_1188del321 MECP2 variant... The mother was negative for the mutation. Therefore, this child carries a de novo mutation." cases.cohort_name: Sri Lankan RTT cohort (Human Genetics Unit, University of Colombo)
cases.family_history: Firstborn to a nonconsanguineous couple; mother negative for the variant
cases.notes: Severe phenotype with scoliosis, EEG abnormalities, focal seizures, hyperactivity/crying episodes.
quotes: |            16 |                          6.5 | c.868_1188del321 | Lacks 107 a.a        | Frameshift | Novel        | (Table 2)
| 16 | 1 | Y | Y | Y | Y | N | Y b                                        | Y | Y | N | N | Y | N | N | N | (Table 3 row for Proband 16)
- b Hyperactivity and periodic crying episodes
The patient with the large deletion (c.868_1188del321) was a girl, she was the firstborn child to a nonconsanguineous couple.
She developed focal convulsions. Her EEG showed focal changes and she was placed on antiepileptics.
At the age of 7 years, she was wheelchair-bound and only spoke 2-3 words.
She was heterozygous for c.868_1188del321 MECP2 variant (Fig. 1).
The mother was negative for the mutation. Therefore, this child carries a de novo mutation.

phenotypic_evidence.core_asd_symptoms: Autism Spectrum disorder/Behavior changes marked present (hyperactivity, periodic crying episodes).
phenotypic_evidence.cognitive_ability_cautionary_comment: Insufficient information on intellectual ability; severe clinical phenotype described but no formal IQ testing reported.
phenotypic_evidence.developmental_milestones: Normal early development; gross motor delay noted at 9 months; regression at 1 year; by 7 years wheelchair-bound and limited speech (2–3 words).
phenotypic_evidence.comorbidities: Focal seizures; EEG abnormalities (focal changes); scoliosis; hyperactivity; periodic crying episodes.
phenotypic_evidence.phenotypes: Classic Rett syndrome with severe phenotype.

variant.variant_description: Novel large deletion in MECP2 TRD domain causing frameshift and truncation (~107 amino acids lost).
variant.segregation_data: Mother tested negative; consistent with de novo origin.

Case 3 of Zappella [1992] has another sister with classic RTT (Fig. 1a). … the other with a diagnosis of PSV (here patient 139.CA). This patient is now a 29-year-old girl: she is still able to speak in short phrases … is hypotonic and is clearly in the fourth stage of motor deterioration. (Patients)

All the mutations identified are de novo except for the 1157del32 which has been found in the preserved speech variant, in her sister (a classic Rett girl) and in their mother (Fig. 3). (Mutation Analysis)

author: Levy D, et al.

cases.description: The deletion of DDX53 in a male proband from family 12561 is the first known ASD-associated de novo mutation at this locus.
cases.notes: X-linked gene; de novo deletion in male proband implies hemizygous loss. File reference: Main text - Discussion.
quotes: More recently, maternally inherited deletions at the X-linked DDX53 locus (encoding a DEAD-box RNA helicase of unknown function) have been linked to ASDs in males (Pinto et al., 2010). The deletion of DDX53 in a male proband from family 12561 is the first known ASD-associated de novo mutation at this locus.
For convenience, throughout this report we refer to the children with diagnosed ASDs as 'probands'.

title: Cytogenetic and molecular-cytogenetic studies of Rett syndrome (RTT): a retrospective analysis of a Russian cohort of RTT patients (the investigation of 57 girls and three boys)
author: Vorsanova SG, et al.

cases.description: A 3.5-year-old boy was the first-born child of unrelated parents... During the following months deterioration was noted. The patient had rapidly lost his vocabulary and started dropping objects that he held in his hands. Purposeful hand use was lost at 20 months. At the same time autistic behavior became evident...
cases.family_history: There was a very distant relative (the daughter of a great grand aunt from the maternal side) who suffered from psychosis. The proband's mother had myopy.
cases.notes: Classical RTT. MECP2 early truncating mutation R270X (hotspot 808C>T) reported. Mosaic 47,XXY detected in muscle (14% interphase nuclei), with normal blood/skin.
quotes: One boy with normal karyotype in lymphocytes and a 'classical' clinical picture of RTT has common early truncating mutation R270X (Maria-Luisa Giovannucci Uzielly, pers. commun.).

The second RTT male has normal karyotype in blood and skin cells, however, we have detected aberrant clone 47,XXY in muscles of this boy. Common early truncated mutation R270X was found in blood cells of this boy (Maria-Luisa Giovannucci Uzielly, pers. commun.).
hotspot (808C . T)

However, interphase analysis of 200 muscle cells showed an abnormal clone containing two X chromosomes in 14% of interphase cells (Fig. 2, Table 1). The result of molecular-cytogenetic diagnosis was nuc ish.Xp11.1-q11.1 (pYAM10-40x2)[28]/Xp11.1-q11.1 (pYAM10-40x1)[172].
During the following months deterioration was noted. The patient had rapidly lost his vocabulary... Purposeful hand use was lost at 20 months. At the same time autistic behavior became evident...
Stereotypical hand movements ... Hand wringing and sucking
They fulfilled all criteria of classical RTT, as defined by The Rett Syndrome Diagnosis Criteria Work Group [12].

phenotypic_evidence.core_asd_symptoms: Autistic behavior; language regression; loss of purposeful hand use; stereotyped hand movements (hand wringing and sucking); social contact disturbance
phenotypic_evidence.diagnostic_criteria_used: Diagnostic criteria for Rett syndrome; classical RTT
phenotypic_evidence.developmental_milestones: Sat 7 mo; stood and had ~10 words at 9 mo; walked with support 18 mo; loss of hand use at 20 mo; regression after 12 mo
phenotypic_evidence.comorbidities: Gait dyspraxia; dystonia of upper limbs; spasticity in lower limbs; hyperreflexia; slight scoliosis; paroxysmal hyperventilation; vasomotor disturbances of lower limbs; no seizures reported

variant.variant: MECP2: early truncating mutation R270X (hotspot 808C>T); plus mosaic 47,XXY detected in muscle (nuc ish Xp11.1–q11.1 (pYAM10-40x2)[28]/(pYAM10-40x1)[172]) with normal blood/skin karyotype
variant.variant_description: Nonsense mutation R270X in MECP2 (reported as common early truncating mutation; hotspot 808C>T). Interphase FISH shows 14% of muscle nuclei with two X signals; blood and skin without detectable aneuploid clone.
variant.segregation_data: Mosaic 47,XXY present in muscle; mother mosaic sex chromosome aneuploidy (45,X/46,XX) per cohort mothers of RTT males (Table 2).

title: Classic Rett syndrome in a boy with R133C mutation of MECP2
author: Masuyama T, et al.

cases.description: Boy with classic Rett syndrome carrying an MECP2 R133C missense mutation; hemizygous with maternal origin. Clinical course includes autistic tendencies, stereotypic hand movements, seizures, loss of mobility leading to being bed-ridden by 8 years.
cases.family_history: Mother heterozygous MECP2 R133C with very mild intellectual impairment; sister heterozygous R133C with classic RTT.
cases.notes: Normal 46,XY karyotype; no evidence of somatic mosaicism. MRI with mild frontal/temporal atrophy. Managed with noninvasive ventilation and tube feeding by age 10. File reference: Main text: Title, Abstract, Section 2 Case report, Section 4 Results; Figure 2(A).
quotes: Classic Rett syndrome in a boy with R133C mutation of MECP2
We report herein a boy with classic RTT in a family with a missense mutation in MECP2.
The R133C mutation was present in MECP2 without somatic mosaicism.
The C-to-T change at 397 in exon 4 of MECP2 that resulted in R133C was detected in three members of this family (Fig. 2(A)).

The mother and the sister were heterozygous for R133C (Fig. 2(A): M and S), and the boy had only one allele, C133, derived from the mother (Fig. 2(A): P). The father displayed a wild-type allele, Rl33 (Fig. 2(A): F).
At this time, strong interest was shown in sound-producing toys, with little interest towards people, indicating autistic tendencies.
At 5-years-old, stereotypic hand movements were observed (Fig. 1).
At about 4-years-old, the patient suffered generalized convulsions.
He became bed-ridden by 8-years-old.
Chromosome analysis revealed a 46, XY karyotype.

phenotypic_evidence.core_asd_symptoms: Autistic tendencies; stereotypic hand movements; loss of purposeful hand use.
phenotypic_evidence.developmental_milestones: Delayed milestones: head control at 6 months; rolling at 7 months; bare sitting and creeping at 13 months; never crawled; regression with loss of mobility by 7–8 years.
phenotypic_evidence.comorbidities: Generalized convulsions; hypotonia; rigidity and dystonic hypertonicity; dystonic posture; thoracic scoliosis; feeding difficulties requiring gastric tube; irregular breathing during wakefulness.
phenotypic_evidence.phenotypes: Classic Rett syndrome phenotype with regression and stereotypic hand movements.

variant.variant_description: c.397C>T (reported as C-to-T at 397) leading to p.R133C; no somatic mosaicism; normal 46,XY karyotype.
variant.impact: Missense change at critical residue in MBD associated with Rett syndrome.
variant.segregation_data: Mother heterozygous R133C; father wild-type; proband hemizygous R133C derived from mother.

cases.score_rationale: Variant: missense (maternal) | Initial score: 0.1 (range: 0-0.1) | Genotypic downgrades: Sequencing method not provided: -0.5 | Final quantized score: 0.0

cases.description: Sequence analysis of the MECP2 gene at 6 years 8 months revealed a c.1164_1184 indel disease-causing mutation with random X-chromosome inactivation. On formal evaluation at 8 years and 2 months, which included ADOS/ADI, she did not satisfy the criteria for autism as she proved to be a very social child often initiating social interactions, using appropriate eye contact which she maintains for stretches longer than 20 s at a time, and directing facial expressions appropriately. She was diagnosed largely due to her unusual interests and obsessive behavior to have obsessive compulsive disorder (OCD) and attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), apart from her global developmental delay (GDD).

title: Lost in translation: translational interference from a recurrent mutation in exon 1 of MECP2
author: Saxena A, et al.

cases.description: In a sample from one atypical RTT patient (212), a smaller band was also observed, which upon sequencing revealed a previously reported 11 nucleotide deletion in exon 1 (c.47_57del GCGAGGAGGAG). The proband was a female... Around 18 months she appeared to be socially disengaged and had autistic traits.
cases.notes: Immunocytochemistry showed MeCP2 protein absent in 24–26% of lymphocytes; XCI 73:27 and 74:26. First diagnosis recorded as Autism; clinically diagnosed Rett syndrome (atypical). Seizures starting ~3 years. Source location in paper: Results (Proband); Detection of an 11 nucleotide deletion; Table 2; Absence of MeCP2 in the peripheral lymphocytes; X chromosome inactivation studies.
quotes: In a sample from one atypical RTT patient (212), a smaller band was also observed, which upon sequencing revealed a previously reported 11 nucleotide deletion in exon 1 (c.47_57del GCGAGGAGGAG) (fig 1A,B).
The proband was a female born by spontaneous vertex delivery...
Around 18 months she appeared to be socially disengaged and had autistic traits.
First diagnosis Autism
Age in 2005 13 years
Seizures, which started at around 3 years, have responded partially to carbamazepine.
evaluation of MeCP2 protein in uncultured patient lymphocytes by immunocytochemistry revealed that MeCP2 protein production was restricted to only 74-76% of lymphocytes.
X chromosome inactivation studies of genomic DNA revealed similar XCI ratios at the HUMARA locus (73:27 with Hpa II and 74:26 with Mcr BC).

phenotypic_evidence.core_asd_symptoms: Autism diagnosis; social disengagement noted at ~18 months; developmental regression with speech deterioration at ~30 months.
phenotypic_evidence.cognitive_ability_cautionary_comment: Insufficient information to classify intellectual ability.
phenotypic_evidence.developmental_milestones: Sat 5.5 months; crawled 12 months; walked 21 months; first words 18 months; speech began to deteriorate ~30 months; loss of hand use and hand stereotypies at 36 months.
phenotypic_evidence.comorbidities: Rett syndrome (atypical); epilepsy (seizures starting ~3 years); constipation; bruxism; periodic rapid breathing; no scoliosis reported.
phenotypic_evidence.phenotypes: Developmental regression; hand stereotypies; partial absence of MeCP2 protein in lymphocytes; skewed XCI ~73:27.

variant.region: exon 1; coding for MeCP2_e1; 5′UTR for MeCP2_e2
variant.variant_description: The mutation is an 11 base pair deletion 46 bases downstream from the start codon in exon 1 (c.47_57del GCGAGGAGGAG). In MeCP2_e1 this causes a frameshift truncation after amino acid 36. In MeCP2_e2 the deletion lies within the 5′-UTR (103 nt upstream of the e2 start codon), with likely translational impact.
variant.impact: Frameshift truncation of MeCP2_e1 after amino acid 36; reduction/ablation of MeCP2_e2 translation due to 5′UTR deletion.

title: Asperger syndrome and early-onset schizophrenia associated with a novel MECP2 deleterious missense variant
author: Curie A, et al.

cases.description: “Both patients fulfilled the Pervasive Developmental Disorder criteria on Autism Diagnostic Observation Schedule and Asperger syndrome criteria on Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, 4th ed. (DSM-IV).” “We found a c.491G > T [ChrX:153296788C > A (Hg19)] transversion in exon 4 of the MECP2 gene in both patients. It was predicted to change a highly conserved serine to isoleucine, p.(Ser164Ile).” “Patient 1 had a very heterogeneous profile: a verbal IQ of 121 and a performance IQ of 58. A diagnosis of dyspraxia was made.” “At 9 years, he had delusional ideas with interpreting processes, and was hearing interior voices. Early-onset schizophrenia was therefore suspected.”
cases.family_history: Dizygotic twins born to unrelated healthy parents; mother and sister lacked the variant in blood DNA, suggesting maternal germline mosaicism.
cases.notes: ADOS module 3 score 12 (cutoff ASD: 10). Early-onset puberty at 8 years 6 months; hyperammonemia under sodium valproate; psychotic relapses at ages 9–11; dyspraxia; heterogeneous WISC-III profile (high VIQ vs low PIQ).
quotes: “Here, we report on two high-functioning brothers who have Asperger's syndrome and early-onset schizophrenia that are associated with a novel pathogenic MECP2 deleterious variant…” [Introduction/Abstract]

“Both patients fulfilled the Pervasive Developmental Disorder criteria on Autism Diagnostic Observation Schedule and Asperger syndrome criteria on Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, 4th ed. (DSM-IV).” [Abstract]
“Both patients fulfilled the criteria for autistic spectrum disorder on ADOS (Table 1) and Asperger syndrome on DSM-IV.” [Neuropsychological and psychiatric assessment]
“ADOS - generic module 3 (cutoff autistic spectrum disorder: 10) | 12 | …” [Table 1]
“Patient 1 had a very heterogeneous profile: a verbal IQ of 121 and a performance IQ of 58. A diagnosis of dyspraxia was made.” [Neuropsychological and psychiatric assessment]
“At 9 years, he had delusional ideas with interpreting processes, and was hearing interior voices. Early-onset schizophrenia was therefore suspected.” [Patient 1]
“Psychiatric diagnosis (DSM-IV TR criteria) | Asperger syndrome, early-onset schizophrenia …” [Table 1]

“We found a c.491G > T [ChrX:153296788C > A (Hg19)] transversion in exon 4 of the MECP2 gene in both patients. It was predicted to change a highly conserved serine to isoleucine, p.(Ser164Ile) (Fig. 1).” [Genetic analysis]

“Electropherograms show that the two affected dizygotic twins (II2 and II3) carry the c.491 G > T; p.(Ser164Ile) transversion of MECP2, whereas only the normal allele is seen in the mother’s (I2) and sister’s blood DNA. This suggests a maternal germline mosaicism.” [Fig. 1 caption]
“The mutation was not observed in blood-extracted DNA from the mother, suggesting germline mosaicism.” [Genetic analysis]

“Age-related Wechsler Scale (WISC-III) was performed in both patients … Patient 1 had a very heterogeneous profile: a verbal IQ of 121 and a performance IQ of 58.” [Neuropsychological and psychiatric assessment]
“At 8 years and 6 months, he showed a central early-onset puberty.” [Patient 1]

“Ten days later, he showed major asthenia and extrapyramidal symptoms. Biological analysis indicated a major hyperammonemia (673 µmol/l) that decreased again to normal values after valproate withdrawal.” [Patient 1]

phenotypic_evidence.core_asd_symptoms: difficulties in social interactions, including inappropriate responses and a lack of social and emotional reciprocity; ritualized behavior and stereotypies.
phenotypic_evidence.diagnostic_criteria_used: DSM-IV / DSM-IV-TR Asperger syndrome; ADOS confirmed ASD.
phenotypic_evidence.assessment_tools_used: ADOS (module 3); WISC-III; Trail Making Test A
phenotypic_evidence.cognitive_assessment_results: WISC-III: verbal IQ 121; performance IQ 58. Trail Making Test A showed impaired mental flexibility. Diagnosis of dyspraxia.
phenotypic_evidence.cognitive_ability_cautionary_comment: Marked VIQ > PIQ discrepancy; dyspraxia may confound performance subtests.
phenotypic_evidence.developmental_milestones: Age at walking 16 months; age at first words 12 months.
phenotypic_evidence.comorbidities: Early-onset schizophrenia (two acute psychotic episodes/relapses); major hyperammonemia under sodium valproate; central early-onset puberty; anxiety, depression, phobia; dyspraxia.
phenotypic_evidence.phenotypes: Clumsiness and fine motor difficulties; social withdrawal; hypersomnia and hyperphagia under treatment.

variant.variant_description: Novel MECP2 transversion in exon 4; not reported in Rett or control databases; located two nucleotides downstream of MBD end; identified due to clinical features including early-onset schizophrenia and hyperammonemia.
variant.impact: Predicted deleterious by SIFT=0, MutationTaster=1, PolyPhen-2=0.998; changes a highly conserved serine to isoleucine.
variant.segregation_data: Two affected dizygotic twins (II2, II3) carry the variant; mother (I2) and sister negative in blood DNA; suggests maternal germline mosaicism.

cases.score_rationale: Variant: missense (unknown) | Initial score: 0.1 (range: 0-0.1) | Genotypic downgrades: Sequencing method not provided: -0.5 | Final quantized score: 0.0

cases.description: “Both patients fulfilled the Pervasive Developmental Disorder criteria on Autism Diagnostic Observation Schedule and Asperger syndrome criteria on Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, 4th ed. (DSM-IV).” “We found a c.491G > T [ChrX:153296788C > A (Hg19)] transversion in exon 4 of the MECP2 gene in both patients. It was predicted to change a highly conserved serine to isoleucine, p.(Ser164Ile).” “Patient 2 also had dyspraxia and striking similarities to his brother in terms of his neuropsychological profile, with lower cognitive skills: a verbal IQ of 83 and a performance IQ of 56.”
cases.family_history: Dizygotic twins born to unrelated healthy parents; mother and sister lacked the variant in blood DNA, suggesting maternal germline mosaicism.
cases.notes: ADOS module 3 score 14 (cutoff ASD: 10). No acute psychotic episodes recorded; dyspraxia; anxiety and ritual behaviors; responded to risperidone for social/behavioral symptoms.
quotes: “Patients 1 and 2 are dizygotic twins, born to unrelated healthy parents (Fig. 1a).” [Clinical data]
“Both patients fulfilled the criteria for autistic spectrum disorder on ADOS (Table 1) and Asperger syndrome on DSM-IV.” [Neuropsychological and psychiatric assessment]
“ADOS - generic module 3 (cutoff autistic spectrum disorder: 10) | … | 14” [Table 1]
“Patient 2 also had dyspraxia … with lower cognitive skills: a verbal IQ of 83 and a performance IQ of 56.” [Neuropsychological and psychiatric assessment]
“At 3 years old, clumsiness, aggressiveness, and opposition were noted at school. He had obsessive concerns with cleanliness.” [Patient 2]
“At 6 years, he was very anxious and had ritual behaviors.” [Patient 2]

“At 7 years, he had unusual social interactions, was overwhelmed by his imaginary world, and showed poor adjustment to his environment. Amitriptyline was replaced by risperidone, which seemed to be effective.” [Patient 2]

“We found a c.491G > T [ChrX:153296788C > A (Hg19)] transversion in exon 4 of the MECP2 gene in both patients. It was predicted to change a highly conserved serine to isoleucine, p.(Ser164Ile) (Fig. 1).” [Genetic analysis]

“Electropherograms show that the two affected dizygotic twins (II2 and II3) carry the c.491 G > T; p.(Ser164Ile) transversion of MECP2, whereas only the normal allele is seen in the mother’s (I2) and sister’s blood DNA. This suggests a maternal germline mosaicism.” [Fig. 1 caption]

phenotypic_evidence.core_asd_symptoms: Unusual social interactions and poor adjustment to environment; very anxious with ritual behaviors.
phenotypic_evidence.diagnostic_criteria_used: DSM-IV / DSM-IV-TR Asperger syndrome; ADOS confirmed ASD.
phenotypic_evidence.cognitive_assessment_results: WISC-III: verbal IQ 83; performance IQ 56. Dyspraxia noted.
phenotypic_evidence.cognitive_ability_cautionary_comment: Low PIQ relative to VIQ; dyspraxia may impact performance tasks.
phenotypic_evidence.developmental_milestones: Age at walking 14 months; age at first words 15 months.
phenotypic_evidence.comorbidities: Dyspraxia; anxiety; obsessive/ritual behaviors; temper tantrums; no acute psychotic episodes.
phenotypic_evidence.phenotypes: Clumsiness; monotonous and annoying voice; difficulty with fine motor tasks (tying shoes, buttoning).

variant.variant_description: Novel MECP2 transversion in exon 4; not reported in Rett or control databases; identified due to neuropsychiatric presentation without intellectual disability.
variant.impact: Predicted deleterious by SIFT=0, MutationTaster=1, PolyPhen-2=0.998; changes a highly conserved serine to isoleucine.
variant.segregation_data: Two affected dizygotic twins (II2, II3) carry the variant; mother (I2) and sister negative in blood DNA; suggests maternal germline mosaicism.
